optionalfeature.name: Passive Innovation: Arcane Vision
entries: {@bold Repeatble:} No
While maintaining this Innovation, you can cast {@spell Detect Magic} at will, without needing a spell slot.

optionalfeature.name: Passive Innovation: Chromatic Surge
entries: {@bold Repeatble:} No

Choose one damage type: Acid, Cold, Fire, Lightning, Poison, or Thunder. While maintaining this Innovation, any spell you cast that deals the chosen damage type adds additional damage equal to your Intelligence modifier. You can choose a different damage type for this Innovation when you finish a long rest.

optionalfeature.name: Passive Innovation: Chromatic Resistance
entries: {@bold Repeatble:} No

Choose one damage type from Acid, Cold, Fire, Lightning, Poison, or Thunder when you maintain this Innovation. You gain resistance to the chosen damage type. The chosen resistance can be changed at the end of a long rest.

optionalfeature.name: Passive Innovation: Architect's Armor
entries: {@bold Repeatble:} No
While maintaining this Innovation, your Armor Class increases by an amount equal to half your proficiency bonus (rounded down).

optionalfeature.name: Passive Innovation: Mask of the Architect
entries: {@bold Repeatble:} No
While maintaining this Innovation, you can cast {@spell Disguise Self} at will without needing a spell slot.

optionalfeature.name: Passive Innovation: Arcane Step
entries: {@bold Repeatble:} Up to 3 Times
You can cast the {@spell Misty Step} spell once per day without expending a spell slot. This ability resets at the end of a long rest.

optionalfeature.name: Passive Innovation: Focus Stabilizer
entries: {@bold Repeatble:} No

When you fail a Constitution saving throw to maintain concentration on a spell, you can use your reaction to automatically succeed instead. This Innovation has 4 charges. It regains {@spell 1d4} expended charges at the end of a long rest.

optionalfeature.name: Passive Innovation: Crystal Clarity
entries: {@bold Repeatble:} No
You gain advantage on Intelligence (Arcana) checks and the ability to identify the properties of magical objects or spells with 10 minutes of study.

optionalfeature.name: Passive Innovation: Arcane Link
entries: {@bold Repeatble:} No

You can telepathically communicate with a willing creature within 60 feet of you as long as you are both conscious. The telepathic bond lasts until the end of a long rest or until this Innovation is no longer maintained.

optionalfeature.name: Passive Innovation: Focused Perception
entries: {@bold Repeatble:} No
While maintaining this Innovation, you can add your Intelligence modifier to Wisdom (Perception) checks.

optionalfeature.name: Passive Innovation: Enhanced Mobility
entries: {@bold Repeatble:} Up to 3 Times
While this Innovation is maintained, your walking speed increases by 10 feet, and your movement is unaffected by difficult terrain.

optionalfeature.name: Passive Innovation: Arcane Fortification
entries: {@bold Repeatble:} Up to 3 Times
While this Innovation is active, you choose a saving throw that you lack proficiency in, you are now proficient in it.

optionalfeature.name: Passive Innovation: Overclocked Crystals
entries: {@bold Repeatble:} No

When you cast a spell that deals damage, you may reroll a number of damage dice equal to your Intelligence modifier (minimum 1). You must use the new rolls. You can use this Innovation once per long rest. This effect does not stack with similar abilities.

optionalfeature.name: Passive Innovation: Adaptive Defenses
entries: {@bold Repeatble:} No

While this Innovation is active, you can use your reaction to impose disadvantage on an attack roll made against you. You can use this ability a number of times equal to half your proficiency bonus (rounded down). Expended uses are restored at the end of a long rest.

optionalfeature.name: Passive Innovation: Long-Distance Transfer
entries: {@bold Repeatble:} No
You can cast the {@spell Teleport} spell once per day without expending a spell slot. This use of {@spell Teleport} recharges after you finish a long rest.

optionalfeature.name: Passive Innovation: Gateway Engineer
entries: {@bold Repeatble:} No
You can cast the {@spell Teleportation Circle} spell once per day without expending a spell slot. This use of {@spell Teleportation Circle} recharges after you finish a long rest.

optionalfeature.name: Passive Innovation: Spectral Vision
entries: {@bold Repeatble:} No
While this innovation is active, you gain {@sense truesight} of 30ft.

optionalfeature.name: Passive Innovation: Alerted Architect
entries: {@bold Repeatble:} No
While this innovation is active, you gain Advantage on rolling Initiative.

optionalfeature.name: Passive Innovation: Technical Armor
entries: {@bold Repeatble:} No
While this innovation is active, you gain proficiency in medium armor, allowing you to equip and effectively use it for increased protection.

optionalfeature.name: Passive Innovation: Skilled Architect
entries: {@bold Repeatble:} Up to 3 Times
While this innovation is active, you gain proficiency in one skill of your choice.

optionalfeature.name: Active Innovation: Reinforce Object
entries: As a bonus action, you can spend 2 Innovation Points to magically reinforce a single non-magical stationary object of size Large or smaller that you touch, such as a door, a section of a wall, or a similar structure. The reinforced object gains a damage threshold of 5, meaning it only takes damage from attacks or effects that deal 5 or more damage in a single instance. Damage below this threshold is negated entirely, as the object is treated as immune to it.

For every additional 2 Innovation Points you spend beyond the initial cost, the damage threshold increases by 5, to a maximum threshold of 20. Similarly, for every additional 2 Innovation Points spent, the duration of the reinforcement increases by 1 hour, up to a maximum duration of 4 hours. The reinforcement ends when the duration expires or if the object is destroyed.

optionalfeature.name: Active Innovation: Crystalline Armor
entries: As a bonus action, you can spend 4 Innovation Points to form a magical crystalline armor over your body, bristling with sharp arcane spikes. While the armor is active, you have advantage on checks to escape being grappled. Additionally, whenever a creature within 5 feet of you hits you with a melee attack, they take 2d6 force damage. You can hold concentration on this effect as if it was a spell for up to 1 minute or until you dismiss it as a bonus action.

optionalfeature.name: Active Innovation: Energized Weapon
entries: As a bonus action, you can spend 2 Innovation Points to enhance a weapon with additional energy. On your next damage roll with the weapon, add 2d4 force damage to the total. For every additional 2 Innovation Points spent, the force damage increases by {@dice 2d4}.

optionalfeature.name: Active Innovation: Energized Weapon
entries: As a bonus action, spend 2 Innovation Points to grant an ally within 30 feet temporary hit points equal to {@dice 1d6} + your Intelligence modifier. For every additional 2 Innovation Points spent, the temporary hit points increase by an additional {@dice 1d6}.

optionalfeature.name: Active Innovation: Arcane Aegis
entries: As a bonus action, you project an arcane shield around an ally within 30 feet of you. The target gains a +1 bonus to their Armor Class for 1 minute.

optionalfeature.name: Active Innovation: Restoration Surge
entries: As a bonus action, you release a pulse of restorative energy toward an ally within 30 feet. The target regains hit points equal to {@dice 2d8} + your Intelligence modifier.

race.name: Steelborn (Warforged)
entries: {@bold Age.} The maximum Steelborn lifespan remains a mystery; so far, Steelborn have shown no signs of deterioration due to age. You are immune to magical aging effects.
{@bold Alignment.} Most Steelborn take comfort in order and discipline, tending toward law and neutrality. But some have absorbed the morality, or lack thereof, of the beings with which they served.
{@bold Constructed Resilience.} You were created to have remarkable fortitude, represented by the following benefits:

items: You have advantage on saving throws against being {@condition poisoned}, and you have resistance to poison damage.
You don't need to eat, drink, or breathe.
You are immune to drugs of any kind.
You are immune to disease.
You don't need to sleep, and magic can't put you to sleep.
You cannot be made undead.

entries: {@bold Sentry's Rest.} When you take a long rest, you must spend at least six hours in an inactive, motionless state, rAether than sleeping. In this state, you appear inert, but it doesn't render you unconscious, and you can see and hear as normal.
{@bold Integrated Protection.} Your body has built-in defensive layers, which can be enhanced with armor:

items: You gain a +1 bonus to Armor Class.

You can don only armor with which you have proficiency. To don armor other than a shield, you must incorporate it into your body over the course of 1 hour, during which you remain in contact with the armor. To doff armor, you must spend 1 hour removing it. You can rest while donning or doffing armor in this way.
While you live, the armor incorporated into your body can't be removed against your will.

entries: {@bold Specialized Design.} You gain one skill proficiency and one tool proficiency of your choice.
{@bold Steel Build.} You are considered heavy for any mechanical rulings that require it.

Steelborn are physically impressive humanoids made up of magically enchanted materials. The 'Skin' of a Steelborn are made of hardened materials such as metal. Beneath this lay the skeleton, made up of similar materials, and the 'musculature' of the Steelborn, are made up of different kinds of metal like materials. Throughout the body of the Steelborn are vessels resembling the circulatory system of organic creatures, complete with a green blood-like fluid. The arms of a Steelborn end in hands with four fingers and a thumb, just like their human counterparts. And the feet of the constructs end in a two-toed form.

Steelborn are a rare race of humanoid constructs. While the creation of these creatures are still unknown in the world of Lumeeria, it's been theorized that capable engineers of the arcane, that reside among the stars, created them. At the year 629 ATL Arcane engineers and Artificers have still not been successful in the recreation of a Steelborn

Steelborn average everywhere from 4-8ft tall, all depending on their design and are made up of bulky (albeit resilient) metallic or stone bodies that weigh roughly 200-300lb (90-140kg) Extremely powerful and durable, Steelborn are able fighters. Unlike most constructs, Steelborn are fully self-aware and maintain mental faculties on par with elves, humans or similar races. The natural lifespan for Steelborn are still unknown.

entries.name: Internal Workings
entries: The Internal Workings of the Steelborn are still do this day is a unknown subject for most.
{@italic Further research is needed for a clear description}

items: {@bold Core}
{@bold Crystaline}
{@bold Soul}
{@bold Repairs}

entries.name: Common Personalities
entries: Steelborn as a whole have a strong work ethic and share an aversion to failure. Steelborn are capable of fear, often of death or pain, as much as other races and can come to hate the sources of these fears just as easily. Steelborn are also capable of loyalty and joy, particularly in relations to friends and allies and can be driven to anger when their loves or goals were threatened.
Quirks. Steelborn sometimes display an odd personality trait or two. The Steelborn Quirks table contains example quirks.

rows: You analyze—out loud—the potential threat posed by every creature you meet.
You are fiercely protective of your friends.
You try to apply wartime discipline to every situation.
You don't know how to filter your feelings and are prone to dramatic emotional outbursts.
You don't understand clothing beyond its utility and assume it denotes a person's function.
You are obsessed with your appearance and constantly polish and buff yourself.
War is the only thing that makes sense to you, and you're always looking for a fight.

entries.name: Creature Type
entries: You are a Humanoid. You are also considered an elf for any prerequisite or effect that requires you to be an elf.

entries.name: Age
entries: Valtarians mature very slowly, only reaching physical and mental maturity at the age of 100 and they can live to be 1000 years.

entries.name: Arctic Resistance
entries: You have resistance to cold damage

entries.name: Darkvision
entries: You can see in dim light within 60 feet of you as if it were bright light and in darkness as if it were dim light. You discern colors in that darkness only as shades of gray.

entries.name: Fey Ancestry
entries: You have advantage on saving throws you make to avoid or end the charmed condition on yourself.

entries.name: Trance
entries: Valtarians don't need to sleep. Instead, they meditate deeply, remaining semiconscious, for 4 hours a day. (The Common word for such meditation is 'trance'.) While meditating, you can dream after a fashion; such dreams are actually mental exercises that have become reflexive through years of practice. After resting in this way, you gain the same benefit that a human does from 8 hours of sleep.

entries.name: Languages
entries: You can speak, read, and write Common and Sylvan

entries.name: Subrace
entries: Choose between Frostweavers or Glacial Wardens

entries.name: Size
entries: Frostweavers range from under 5 to over 6 feet tall and have slender builds. Your size is Medium.

entries.name: Blessings of the Frost Queen
entries: You know the {@spell Frostbite|xge} and {@spell Ray of Frost} cantrip. Starting at 3rd level, you can cast the {@spell Frost Fingers|idrotf} spell with this trait.  Starting at 5th level, you can also cast the {@spell Sleet storm} spell with this trait. Once you cast {@spell Frost Fingers|idrotf} or {@spell Sleet Storm} with this trait, you can't cast that spell with it again until you finish a long rest. You can also cast either of those spells using any spell slots you have of the appropriate level. Intelligence is your spellcasting ability for these spells when you cast them with this trait.

entries.name: Arcane Connection
entries: You have proficiency in the Arcana skill

entries.name: Size
entries: Glacial Wardens range from under 6 to 8 feet tall and have bulky builds. Your size is Medium.

entries.name: Natural Defender
entries: Your body is extremely robust and even the sharpest of weapons have a hard time piercing your skin at times. You gain a +1 bonus to armor class. As well as your hit point maximum increases by 1, and it increases by 1 every time you gain a level.

entries.name: Born Athlete
entries: You have proficiency in the Athletics skill

The Valtarians are a striking and enigmatic race of fey humanoids that dwell in the North Eastern region of the continent of Karuun. Their appearance is reminiscent of elves but with distinct features that set them apart:

entries.name: Skin Tones
entries: Valtarians possess a range of cool, ethereal skin tones that reflect their affinity with the northern reaches of Karuun. These hues can vary from deep, rich blues to lighter bluish-grays, creating an otherworldly and mesmerizing effect. The skin seems to shimmer softly in the right light, giving them an almost otherworldly glow.

entries.name: Eye Colors
entries: Their eyes are equally captivating, with shades of blue, violet, and silver being the most common. These eye colors can change in intensity based on their emotions and surroundings, creating an alluring and mysterious gaze.

entries.name: Hair
entries: Valtarian hair is often strikingly beautiful. It typically appears as a radiant white, but with subtle undertones of blue, violet, or black, adding to their unique charm. Their hair has a flowing and almost weightless quality, as if it were spun from moonlight.

entries.name: Fur Patches
entries: One of the most distinctive features of Valtarians is the presence of scattered fur patches on their bodies. These patches are strategically placed, enhancing their natural allure. Fur can be found on the front of their thighs, on the back of their calves, along a line running from their waist to their ribcage on each side, and on the top of their biceps. These patches of fur have a soft, velvety texture and usually share the same blue or violet hues as their skin. For Glacial Wardens, these fur patches are even more pronounced and often possess an almost frosty, iridescent quality.

entries.name: Elven Elegance
entries: Valtarians share the graceful and elegant physique commonly associated with elves. They tend to have tall, slender frames with long, lithe limbs. Their movements are fluid and precise, reflecting their natural agility and grace.

entries.name: Clothing
entries: Valtarian attire is often tailored to highlight their unique features. They favor flowing, ethereal fabrics in shades that complement their skin and hair tones. They may wear robes, tunics, or dresses that incorporate intricate patterns and designs inspired by their connection to the icy landscapes of their homeland.

entries.name: Jewelry and Adornments
entries: Valtarians often adorn themselves with jewelry made from precious stones and metals that mirror the colors of their eyes, skin, and fur. These adornments may include intricate necklaces, bracelets, and circlets, all designed to enhance their natural beauty.

entries.name: Description of the Valtarians:
entries: The Valtarians are a remarkable and enigmatic race, bearing both physical and cultural distinctions that set them apart in the icy domains of the North Eastern Karuun. Here's a detailed description of these unique beings:

entries.name: Longevity
entries: Valtarians are known for their exceptional longevity, surpassing even the most ancient of elves. They are considered adults at the remarkable age of 100 and can live up to an astonishing 1000 years, making their existence a testament to the enduring power of their creator, the Frost Queen.

entries.name: Distinct Skin and Hair
entries: Valtarians boast cool, ethereal skin tones, ranging from deep, rich blues to lighter bluish-grays. Their skin seems to shimmer with an otherworldly glow, reflecting their connection to the icy landscapes they inhabit. Their hair is equally captivating, often appearing as radiant white with subtle undertones of blue, violet, or black, evoking the beauty of the frozen landscapes they call home.

entries.name: Fur Patches
entries: One of their most distinctive physical features is the presence of scattered fur patches on specific areas of their bodies. These velvety fur patches share the same hues as their skin and add to their unique charm. Fur can be found on the front of their thighs, on the back of their calves, along a line running from their waist to their ribcage on each side, and on the top of their biceps. For Glacial Wardens, these fur patches are even more pronounced and often possess an almost frosty, iridescent quality.

entries.name: Social Way of Life
entries: Valtarians are inherently social beings, cherishing connections and relationships with their kin. They hold gAetherings and celebrations with great enthusiasm, especially when a new Valtarian child is born into their world. These festivities are marked by storytelling, music, and dancing, with each event serving as a reminder of their enduring bonds as a community.

entries.name: Rich History and Culture
entries: Valtarian culture is steeped in noble stories and traditions. They possess a deep reverence for their creator, the Frost Queen, and their history is filled with tales of resilience, transformation, and unwavering loyalty to their queen.

entries.name: Matriarchal Society
entries: The Valtarian Kingdom is a matriarchy, and the Frost Queen reigns without question as their revered leader. This arrangement reflects their profound belief in the Frost Queen as their Creator and the source of their existence.

entries.name: Subrace
entries: Over countless millennia spent in the Material Plane, the Valtarians evolved under the watchful eye of their creator. Choose between Frostweavers and Glacial Wardens

items: Frostweavers are Valtarians with an elegant and scholarly appearance, often seen in flowing robes of icy blues and silvers. They are known for their intellect and mastery of ice magic, wielding it with precision.

Within Valtarian society, they hold a prominent role as the creators and controllers of the kingdom's magical constructs. Highly respected for their wisdom, they are often found in leadership positions.
In Valtarian society, Frostweavers are valued for their intellectual contributions, and they often advise the Frost Queen. They hold a position of respect, guiding the kingdom's magical endeavors.
Glacial Wardens are Valtarians with a robust and formidable presence, their bodies adorned with pronounced fur patches. They are often seen in armor, their physical prowess evident.
Their key role is protection; they serve as the guardians of the Frostweavers, the kingdom, and its inhabitants. They possess physical strength and combat skills.

In Valtarian society, Glacial Wardens are highly regarded as the stalwart defenders of their kin. While they may have a lower intellect compared to Frostweavers, their dedication to safeguarding their society is unwavering.

entries.name: Age
entries: Fangborn are quick to mature both physically and emotionally, reaching young adulthood at age 15. They can live up to 120 years.

entries.name: Darkvision
entries: You can see in dim light within 60 feet of you as if it were bright light and in darkness as if it were dim light. You can't discern color in darkness, only shades of gray.

entries.name: Claws
entries: Your claws are natural weapons, which you can use to make unarmed strikes as a bonus action. If you hit with them, you can deal slashing damage equal to 1d6 + your Strength modifier or Dexterity modifier, instead of the bludgeoning damage normal for an unarmed strike.

entries.name: Primal Intuition
entries: You have proficiency in three of the following skills of your choice: Animal Handling, Athletics, Intimidation, Medicine, Nature, Perception, and Survival.

entries.name: Thickhide
entries: You have a +1 bonus to your Armor Class

entries.name: Fangborn in Lumeeria
entries: Fangborn can be found in various parts of Lumeeria, with some of the most well-known locations being islands surrounding the mainland. They typically reside in untamed natural environments, living in simple tribal conditions and maintaining hunting traditions. Despite this, Fangborn occasionally integrate into different parts of society.

According to the legends recorded in their tribes, Fangborn were created by Ragnath the Bloodthirster. After observing the world, Ragnath felt it lacked his untamed and bloodthirsty creations. Consequently, Fangborn take pride in their primitive lifestyle, believing it aligns with their creator's vision.

entries.name: Fangborn in Lumeeria
entries: Fangborn exhibit a distinctive and primal appearance, reflecting their connection to nature. While their exact features may vary, they share common characteristics:

entries.name: Bestial Features
entries: Fangborn have pronounced fangs, sharp claws, and often possess animalistic attributes such as pointed ears, wild hair, and glowing eyes. These features highlight their primal nature and give them an intimidating presence.

entries.name: Feral Physique
entries: They have a more robust and muscular build compared to humans, emphasizing their physical prowess and strength. Their bodies are often covered in tribal tattoos or intricate markings, symbolizing their connection to their deity and their tribal identity.

entries.name: Wild Attire
entries: Fangborn typically wear minimalistic clothing made from animal skins, furs, and natural materials. They prioritize practicality over extravagance, with their attire often adorned with teeth, bones, and feAethers as symbols of their hunting prowess.

entries.name: Tribal Decorations
entries: Tribal ornaments and jewelry made from bones, claws, and natural elements are common among the Fangborn. These adornments serve as status symbols, reflecting their achievements and sometimes carrying spiritual significance.

Overall, the appearance of the Fangborn blends their primal nature with their connection to the untamed wilderness. They embody a fierce and untamed aesthetic, reflecting their dedication to the primal forces they revere and their unwavering commitment to protecting their island home.

entries.name: Age
entries: Yeinnen have lifespans similar to humans.

entries.name: Alignment
entries: Yeinnen are often drawn toward neutral and chaotic alignments, reflecting their inherent inclination toward malicious intentions.

entries.name: Size
entries: Yeinnen have the same size and build as humans. Your size is Medium

entries.name: Poison Resistance
entries: ou have advantage on saving throws against poison, and you have resistance against poison damage.

entries.name: Hidden in plain sight
entries: You have proficiency in two of the following skills: Deception, Performance, Stealth or intimidation.

entries.name: Forked Tongue
entries: As an action, you can extend your forked tongue to attempt to kiss a creature within 5 feet of you. The target must make a Dexterity saving throw against a DC of 8 + your proficiency bonus + your Charisma modifier. On a failed save, the creature is injected with poison, taking PB times d10 poison damage. Once you use this ability, you can't use it again until you finish a short or long rest.

entries.name: Languages
entries: You can speak, read, and write in Yeinnen and Common.

entries.name: Forked Tongue with Venomous Webbing
entries: One of the most distinguishing features of the Yeinnen is their forked tongue, split into three sections with webbing between each part. This seemingly innocuous trait conceals a deadly secret— a potent venom capable of causing swift demise to any race except their own. However, when shared among Yeinnen, the venom takes on a different nature, acting as a powerful aphrodisiac that enhances their connection and bonds.

entries.name: Cold-Blooded Nature
entries: Despite outwardly appearing warm-blooded, the Yeinnen are, in fact, cold-blooded like reptiles. This internal coldness remains hidden beneath their human-like exterior, allowing them to seamlessly integrate into human society. However, this characteristic influences their behaviors and preferences, causing them to thrive in warmer environments.

entries.name: Innate Malicious Intentions
entries: A darker aspect of the Yeinnen is their inherent inclination towards malicious intentions. Whether born of their unique physiology or an ancient curse, the Yeinnen often find themselves drawn to deceit, manipulation, and darker pursuits. This predisposition does not necessarily mean every Yeinnen is malevolent, but it is an inherent aspect of their nature.

entries.name: Population and Birthrate
entries: The population of the Yeinnen remains exceptionally low, and they prefer to live concealed among the bustling crowds of large cities, where their unique traits are less likely to draw attention. Their birthrate, especially between a human and a Yeinnen, is remarkably low. However, when two Yeinnen come together, their reproductive abilities return to normal levels.

entries.name: Origin
entries: The origins of the Yeinnen trace back to the millennium of the lost, a mysterious period in Lumeeria's history shrouded in the annals of time. The first appearance of the Yeinnen remains a puzzle, and their scarce population contributes to the air of mystery that surrounds their enigmatic race.

In the intricate tapestry of Lumeeria, the Yeinnen exist as elusive figures, navigating the delicate balance between blending into human society and embracing the peculiarities that define their true nature. The Yeinnen move through the shadows, their secrets known to only a few, as they continue to leave an indelible mark on the world they inhabit.

entries.name: Age
entries: Boyaks mature quickly, reaching adulthood by the age of 12. They commonly live to be around 150 years old.

entries.name: Alignment
entries: Boyaks lean towards chaotic good alignments, embodying a free-spirited and benevolent nature.

entries.name: Dexterous Feet
entries: As a bonus action, you can use your feet with remarkable dexterity. You can manipulate objects, open or close doors or containers, and pick up or set down tiny objects using your feet. This ability allows you to perform simple tasks without using your hands, leaving them free for more complex actions.

entries.name: Prehensile Tail
entries: Your long, prehensile tail is a versatile tool. While you cannot wield weapons with it, your tail allows you to retrieve a small, stowed object carried on your person as a bonus action. The tail has a reach of 15 feet, providing you with an extended range for interacting with objects. The Tail cannot be used for attacking.

entries.name: Sticking the landing
entries: Whenever you take falling damage from a height no greater than 10 x your proficiency bonus. You halve the damage you take.

entries.name: Darkvision
entries: Accustomed to the dimly lit jungles, you can see in dim light within 60 feet of you as if it were bright light, and in darkness as if it were dim light. You can't discern color in darkness, only shades of gray.

entries.name: Languages
entries: You can speak, read, and write in Common and Boyak. Boyak is a unique language, rich in expressive body language and intricate hand signals, allowing for silent communication in the treetops.

entries.name: Description
entries: Boyaks, the agile and intelligent monkey-like humanoids, thrive in the heart of deep, warm forests and lush jungles. Their bodies are covered in a thin coat of soft fur that comes in a variety of colors, including chestnut, ivory, and even golden hues. Despite their fur, Boyaks grow lengthy hair on their heads, mimicking the diverse hairstyles that humans sport. Male and female Boyaks alike take pride in elaborate hairstyles, especially for important social functions, with the hair matching the color of their fur. With long, prehensile tails and hand-like feet capable of articulate movements, Boyaks have adapted seamlessly to their arboreal environments.

Standing at a height ranging from 3'3 to 3'11 feet and weighing around 100 pounds, Boyaks are considered small creatures. One of their most distinctive features is their considerably long arms, a trait that aids them in traversing the dense canopies of their lush habitats.

entries.name: Culture
entries: Boyak culture revolves around their deep connection to the primal rhythms of the forests they call home. They live in close-knit communities within the trees, crafting simple yet efficient treehouses woven from vines and branches. Boyaks possess a profound respect for the natural world and maintain a delicate balance with their surroundings.

entries.name: Social Structure
entries: Boyak communities are led by wise elders who hold extensive knowledge about the jungles and maintain the spiritual traditions of their people. Despite a structured leadership, Boyak society thrives on communal living, with shared responsibilities and a strong sense of cooperation. They engage in communal activities, such as shared meals and intricate grooming rituals, strengthening the bonds within the community.

entries.name: Adornments and Hairstyles
entries: Boyaks express their individuality through elaborate hairstyles adorned with natural ornaments like vibrant flowers, feAethers, and beads. The intricate hairstyles serve not only as a form of personal expression but also convey the individual's role and status within the community.

entries.name: Ceremonial Practice
entries: Boyaks celebrate important life events and natural occurrences with vibrant ceremonies. Births, coming-of-age rituals, and even significant celestial events are marked with dance, song, and communal feasts. These ceremonies are seen as a way to connect with the spirits of the forest and express gratitude for the bounty it provides.

entries.name: Art and Craftsmanship
entries: Boyaks are skilled artisans, creating simple yet elegant tools and crafts from materials found in the jungle. Intricately woven baskets, carved wooden utensils, and natural-fiber clothing reflect their practical yet artistic approach to craftsmanship.

entries.name: Communication
entries: Boyaks communicate not only through spoken language but also through a sophisticated system of hand signals and expressive body language. This silent communication is particularly crucial when traversing the treetops, where vocal communication might alert potential threats.

entries.name: Primal Spirituality
entries: Boyaks possess a deep spiritual connection to the natural world. They revere the spirits of the forest, rivers, and sky, believing in a harmonious balance that must be maintained. Rituals and offerings are made to appease these spirits, seeking their guidance and protection.

In the heart of the dense jungles, Boyaks thrive as the guardians of the ancient trees, the tricksters of the treetops, and the keepers of the primal secrets that echo through the foliage. Their culture, intertwined with the vibrant pulse of the natural world, is a testament to their harmonious existence with the jungles they call home.

entries.name: Age
entries: Ratfolk commonly live a little over 50 years, reaching adulthood at age 15. Their fur turns grey after about 30 years.

entries.name: Size
entries: Ratfolk stand about 5'3” to 5'6” and weigh around 110–120 lbs. Your size is Medium.

entries.name: Alignment
entries: Ratfolk are strongly inclined to follow their own path, preferring freedom over all else, making them strongly chaotic. Most are morally neutral.

entries.name: Darkvision
entries: You can see in dim light within 60 feet of you as if it were bright light, and darkness as if it were dim light. You can't discern color in darkness, only shades of grey.

entries.name: Sneaky
entries: You have proficiency in the Stealth skill.

entries.name: Thin Frame
entries: You can squeeze through spaces as if you were a Small creature.

entries.name: Nimble Hands
entries: You have proficiency in Tinker's Tools, Alchemist's supplies and Cartographer's tools.

entries.name: Toxic Resilience
entries: You have advantage on saving throws against being poisoned, and you have resistance to poison damage.

entries.name: Languages
entries: You can speak, read, and write Common and Vepus.

The Vepus look like a hybrid of a thin human and a rat. They are shorter than humans. and appear almost frail. They have heads shaped like rats, with an elongated skull, thin lips, a Rat's snout, and black, or red orbs for eyes, but no cleft in the mouth. The fur that grows on their bodies is thin, but dark, giving them an obscured appearance in dark conditions, though ratfolk commonly have fur colors ranging from light browns to dark gray and black. Unlike all beastfolk, ratfolk walk on rat-shaped feet, not human-like feet. They have short, thin tails.

Vepus prefers simple clothing with dark hues, preferring black with dark blues, greens, and browns. Most of their clothing is a bit loose fitting for comfort with little in the way of elaborate features or ornamentation. They especially try to keep anything metal covered so nothing shines.

The Vepus are accustomed to hard lives throughout Lumeeria. Most places they are treated only slightly better than Goblins. They are generally only accepted into cities and in society because of their commonly neutral alignment. They can be found all around Lumeeria, in Kudan's Maze, in the sewers of large cities, and in abandoned possibly poisonous areas. Or even some extremely rare cases where a Vepus has risen from the norm and gotten an important social standing.
The Vepus can live anywhere and everywhere. That is why they mostly live in areas where it would be impossible for other races to live as they like to keep to themselves.

The Vepus are naturally introverted and inwardly drawn. They prefer to spend their time on their own and, even in large crowds, try to make it clear they wish to be on their own. This gives them an insightful attitude and they will always speak carefully, with few words and cautious thought. This, by extension, gives Vepus a disdain for authority figures and those in high standing. Many Vepus have little respect for such people as they believe in protecting themselves and righting wrongs done to them on their own
The Vepus are commonly looked down upon all around the world as they are seen as a dirty race by others such as Elves or humans.

A Vepus' adventurer is one who seeks a place in a world where acceptance and acknowledgment for their kind don't come easy. Though Vepuses are cautious, they are neither fearful nor stupid, and the opportunity to face enemies and beat traps give them a sense of challenge. For the Vepus, the chance to complete a task no one else can is exhilarating.  The Vepuses dislike the norms placed on them, but while they don't seek to affect such change in attitude on a large scale, they place great value on the opinions of those few they come to trust. This trust comes with time and much effort and can be lost easily if abused.

entries.name: Age
entries: Kizean mature at a rate similar to humans, reaching adulthood in their late teens. They have an average lifespan of about 400 years.

entries.name: Born of Ice
entries: Due to their icy origins, Kizean have resistance to cold damage and advantage against any natural or magical effects related to cold damage, such as the breath attack of a white dragon or spells like Cone of Cold.

entries.name: One with the Snow
entries: As a bonus action, Kizean can attempt to hide in snow, granting them advantage on any Dexterity (Stealth) checks related to snow. Additionally, they can move up to half their movement while hidden in snow without needing to make a new Dexterity (Stealth) check.

entries.name: Natural Wanderers
entries: Kizean are adept at traversing arctic terrain and ignore difficult terrain caused by snow, ice, or any other effects of arctic climates, including magical effects.

entries.name: Natural Tamers
entries: Kizean have proficiency in the Animal Handling skill, and they gain advantage on Wisdom (Animal Handling) checks related to taming beasts of the arctic climate. Once a Kizean has tamed an arctic beast, a strong bond forms between them, requiring significant effort to break.

entries.name: Languages
entries: Kizean can speak, read, and write Common and Kizean.

entries.name: Physical Description
entries: The Kizean are a hardy race, born and bred in the unforgiving arctic climates of Akihala, Athula, and Navaro. Ranging from 5 to 9 feet in height, they exhibit a wide spectrum of builds, from lean and agile to burly and robust. Their distinctive feature is their four-fingered hands, a characteristic shared among all Kizean. Their skin spans shades of light blue to dark blue, reflecting the icy landscapes they call home. Hair colors vary from shimmering silver to snowy white, with occasional hints of grey or rare flashes of crimson. Their eyes, deep and dark, hold orbs of blackness adorned with irises of light blue, silver, or purple.

entries.name: Society
entries: Kizean society is as diverse as the icy lands they inhabit, with various tribes and kingdoms dotting the frozen landscapes. Some Kizean live nomadic lives, constantly traversing the tundra and setting up temporary camps as they follow the rhythms of the land. These tribes are deeply connected to nature and rely heavily on their innate ability to tame and communicate with beasts.

Others embrace a matriarchal rule, where powerful Frostbringers—those blessed with the magic of Netia, the Snowbringer—lead their people in the construction of grand icy kingdoms. Within these societies, the Frostbringers hold positions of reverence and authority, guiding their people with wisdom and magic. While they still maintain a connection to the natural world, they rely less on beast-taming and instead focus on building formidable structures and harnessing the power of their deity.

entries.name: Religion
entries: The Kizean hold a deep reverence for Netia, the Snowbringer, whom they view as their creator and true mother. Netia embodies the essence of the icy wilderness, bringing both beauty and harshness to their world. Known as the Frostbringers, Kizean shamans who have been blessed with Netia's power wield formidable magic, channeling the frost and snow to protect and sustain their people. While both males and females can become Frostbringers, it is often the females who display a stronger affinity for the Snowbringer's magic, earning them greater respect and authority within Kizean society. The religion of the Kizean is deeply intertwined with their daily lives, guiding their actions, traditions, and rituals as they navigate the frozen expanses of their homeland.

feat.name: Firearms Expert
entries: Thanks to extensive practice with firearms, you gain the following benefits:

items: You ignore the loading quality of firearms with which you are proficient.
Being within 5 feet of a hostile creature doesn't impose disadvantage on your ranged attack rolls with firearms. This counts for weapons with the Scoped Feature too

When you use the Attack action and attack with a one-handed weapon shooting pistol bullets, you can use a bonus action to attack with a different firearm that shoots pistol bullets that you are holding.

entries: This feat enhances your proficiency with firearms, allowing for quicker reloads, improved accuracy in close combat, and the ability to make rapid successive attacks with pistols.

feat.name: Toughened
entries: You have honed your endurance and resilience to a higher degree, becoming even more formidable in combat.

items: Increase your maximum hit points by rolling a toughened die, which is a d4, and adding the result to your hit point total. Roll a toughened die for all previous levels as well.
Each time you gain a level, roll the toughened die and add the result to your hit point total.

entries: This feat enhances the character's durability over time, granting them additional hit points with each level gained. It builds upon the foundation laid by the Tough feat, further solidifying the character's resilience in the face of adversity.

feat.name: Dagger Dance
entries: Thanks to extensive practice with daggers and agility, you gain the following benefits

items: Being within 5 feet of a hostile creature doesn't impose disadvantage on your ranged attack roles with thrown weapons.
When you use the Dash action, difficult terrain doesn't cost you extra movement on that turn.

feat.name: Magical Insight
entries: Your magical ability have granted you an insight into battle.

items: You can give yourself a bonus to your initiative rolls equal to your spellcasting modifier.

feat.name: Talented Preparer
entries: Whether through keen insight, natural charm, or profound intellect, you have unlocked the ability to prepare a greater array of spells.

items: The number of spells you can prepare each day increases by your proficiency bonus.

item.name: Flintlock Pistol
entries: A simple, single-shot firearm featuring a flintlock mechanism. It's the most common firearm found across Lumeeria, favored for its affordability and reliability.

entries.name: Ammunition Type
entries: Pistol Bullets(1 sp)

entries.name: Loading 1
entries: The weapon can be fired a number of times equal to its Reload score before you must spend 1 attack or 1 action to reload. You must have one free hand to reload a firearm.

item.name: Architect's Tools
entries: Architect's Tools are a set of specialized instruments that enable an Architect to perform their craft. These tools are essential for inscribing sigils into Architect's Arcane Crystals, calibrating magical constructs, and conducting arcane research. Without these tools, an Architect cannot prepare new spells or fine-tune their crystals.

items: {@bold Engraving Needle:} For carving intricate sigils into crystals.
{@bold Arcane Lens:} A magnifier for precision work.
{@bold Crystal Clamp:} Holds crystals steady during inscription.
{@bold Tuning Fork:} Tests resonance and ensures proper alignment with Etheria.
{@bold Sigil Scribing:} Inscribing spells onto Architect's Arcane Crystals.
{@bold Calibration:} Adjusting the flow of energy in arcane devices or constructs.
{@bold Research and Repair:} Holds crystals steady during inscription.
{@bold Tuning Fork:} Analyzing raw arcane crystals or repairing damaged components.

entries: Architects rely on their tools and expertise to interact with the arcane engineering of the world. Below are examples of how different ability checks can complement an Architect’s work:

items: {@bold Investigation (Intelligence):} Used to detect hidden mechanisms, spot flaws in constructs, Spotting subtle energy leaks, identifying distortions in the air from a malfunctioning device, noticing cracks in an arcane crystal that indicate imminent failure or analyze clues related to arcane engineering. For example, determining the weak point of a malfunctioning construct or deducing the purpose of a mysterious device.

{@bold Arcana (Intelligence):} A key skill for deciphering and understanding the principles behind arcane engineering. This includes attempting to repair or recalibrate an arcane device, such as an overloaded Architect’s Arcane Crystal, or understanding why a magical construct has malfunctioned.

{@bold History (Intelligence):} Used to uncover the origin, age, and historical significance of an arcane device or construct. For instance, determining whether a construct was created in a long-lost civilization and discovering insights about its purpose.

{@bold Sleight of Hand (Dexterity):} In delicate operations, such as inscribing sigils on an Architect's Arcane Crystal or reattaching intricate mechanisms, this skill ensures precision and care in execution.

entries.name: Proficiency with Architect's Tools
entries: If you are proficient with Architect's Tools, you add your proficiency bonus to any checks made to scribe sigils, modify arcane crystals, or repair constructs.

item.name: Architect's Staff
entries: The Architect's Staff is a specialized tool and spellcasting focus, designed exclusively for Architects. It houses sockets for Architect's Arcane Crystals and channels the energy within them, enabling precise spellcasting. Each staff is a reflection of its creator's ingenuity, often incorporating personal modifications and features.

items: {@bold Crystal Sockets:}The staff contains sockets that securely hold Architect's Arcane Crystals
{@bold Energy Conduit:} The staff channels arcane energy from the crystals into spells, serving as a focus for casting.

entries.name: Alternative Designs
entries: Architects lacking the means to obtain a staff may use alternative spellcasting foci, such as:

items: {@bold Crystal Pouches:} Organized compartments to store and manage prepared crystals.
{@bold Compact Scepters:} Smaller, lightweight versions of the staff with fewer features.

entries.name: Replacement
entries: If your Architect's Staff is lost or destroyed, crafting a new one requires 1 week of downtime and 250 gp worth of materials. You must have access to your Architect's Tools to complete the process.

item.name: Revolver
entries: A multi-shot firearm equipped with a revolving cylinder. It offers rapid firing and increased ammunition capacity compared to flintlock pistols.

entries.name: Ammunition Type
entries: Pistol Bullets(1 sp)

entries.name: Loading 6
entries: The weapon can be fired a number of times equal to its Reload score before you must spend 1 attack or 1 action to reload. You must have one free hand to reload a firearm.

item.name: Musket
entries: A multi-shot firearm equipped with a revolving cylinder. It offers rapid firing and increased ammunition capacity compared to flintlock pistols.

entries.name: Ammunition Type
entries: Musket Rounds (2 sp)

entries.name: Loading 1
entries: The weapon can be fired a number of times equal to its Reload score before you must spend 1 attack or 1 action to reload. You must have one free hand to reload a firearm.

item.name: Rifle
entries: A specialized firearm with a rifled barrel for improved accuracy. Rifles are prized for their long-range capabilities and precision.

entries.name: Ammunition Type
entries: Rifle bullets (3 sp)

entries.name: Loading 1
entries: The weapon can be fired a number of times equal to its Reload score before you must spend 1 attack or 1 action to reload. You must have one free hand to reload a firearm.

item.name: Blunderbuss
entries: A firearm with a short barrel and a flared muzzle, firing a spread of shot or pellets. Blunderbusses excel at close-range combat and crowd control.

entries.name: Ammunition Type
entries: Blunderbuss Bullets (1 sp)

entries.name: Loading 1
entries: The weapon can be fired a number of times equal to its Reload score before you must spend 1 attack or 1 action to reload. You must have one free hand to reload a firearm.

item.name: Shotgun
entries: A close-range firearm with a wide spread, effective for hunting and close-quarters combat. Shotguns deliver devastating damage at short distances.

entries.name: Ammunition Type
entries: Shotgun Shells (2 sp)

entries.name: Loading 2
entries: The weapon can be fired a number of times equal to its Reload score before you must spend 1 attack or 1 action to reload. You must have one free hand to reload a firearm.

item.name: Carbine
entries: A shorter, lighter version of the rifle, favored for its portability and versatility in close to medium-range combat situations.

entries.name: Ammunition Type
entries: Carbine Rounds (4 sp)

entries.name: Loading 8
entries: The weapon can be fired a number of times equal to its Reload score before you must spend 1 attack or 1 action to reload. You must have one free hand to reload a firearm.

item.name: Derringer
entries: A compact, concealable pistol favored by nobles and individuals seeking discreet personal protection. Derringers are known for their small size and reliability.

entries.name: Ammunition Type
entries: Pistol Bullets (4 sp)

entries.name: Loading 2
entries: The weapon can be fired a number of times equal to its Reload score before you must spend 1 attack or 1 action to reload. You must have one free hand to reload a firearm.

item.name: Sniper Rifle
entries: A precision firearm equipped with an arcane telescopic sight for long-range engagements. Sniper rifles are rare and highly sought after for their unmatched accuracy.

entries.name: Scoped
entries: When your within 20ft of your target, you have disadvantage on hitting them.

entries.name: Ammunition Type
entries: Sniper Rounds (10 sp)

entries.name: Loading 1
entries: The weapon can be fired a number of times equal to its Reload score before you must spend 1 attack or 1 action to reload. You must have one free hand to reload a firearm.

item.name: Musket
entries: A multi-shot firearm equipped with a revolving cylinder. It offers rapid firing and increased ammunition capacity compared to flintlock pistols.

entries.name: Ammunition Type
entries: Musket Rounds (2 sp)

entries.name: Loading 1
entries: The weapon can be fired a number of times equal to its Reload score before you must spend 1 attack or 1 action to reload. You must have one free hand to reload a firearm.

variantrule.name: Lumeeria variant: Exhaustion
entries: There are now 10 points of exhaustion with each point from 1 to 9 give a -1 equal to the level of exhaustion one has. If a character reaches 10 points of exhaustion, they die immediately.
A characters speed is halved when they have 5 or more exhaustion points
This affects all your d20 rolls except death saves, meaning all your attack rolls, ability checks, and saving throws.
If you have a spell save DC, that is also lowered equal to your exhaustion points.

entries.name: Skipping Sleep
entries: Skipping sleep for 24 hours prompts one to make a D20 roll.

variantrule.name: Lumeeria variant: Falling
entries: Falling from a great height is a significant risk for adventurers and their foes. At the end of the fall, you take {@dice 1d6} bludgeoning damage for every 10 feet you fell. There is no maximum height. You also land prone, unless you somehow avoid taking damage from the fall, such as with a special ability or the {@spell FeAether Fall|phb} spell.

When you fall from a great height, you instantly descend up to 500 feet. If you're still falling on your next turn, you descend up to 500 feet at the end of that turn. This process continues until the fall ends, either because you hit the ground or the fall is otherwise halted.

variantrule.name: Lumeeria variant: Mastery Feature
entries: Mastery is a new feature that can only be granted through supernatural means.
Mastery acts like another layer of Proficiency, being above Expertise in the sense that it tripples a character's Proficiency Bonus to chosen skill.
A character can only have 1 Mastery Skill at any time.
Mastery gained through an item, should make the item Very Rare.

variantrule.name: Lumeeria variant: Inspiration
entries: Inspirations can stack up to the character's Proficiency Bonus.
If you are granted inspiration while at max, the inspiration is lost.
Inspirations can be given around the table, though certain situations do not allow for this, such as a character being temporarily against the party.

Inspirations work as a reroll of all the dice, including any dice gained from outside sources (Such as Guidance or Bless). If you have advantage on the initial roll and you choose to use inspiration, you roll with advantage again.

variantrule.name: Lumeeria variant: Attunement
entries: Attunement is very important in Dungeons And Dragons, as it limits the amount of magic items a player can possess if the items. The amount of attuned items a player can have at any time is changed from the standard 3 items, now being equal to a character's Proficiency Bonus instead.
The time it takes to attune with a item is changed to an action, though some items can have different attunement times. When you unattune from an item, you lose all abilities and benefits it gives.

variantrule.name: Lumeeria variant: Magic Scrolls
entries: If magic is put into a scroll, then anyone, even people not attuned to the Arcane Realm, can make use of the magic within. However, this only counts for weaker spells, being on the level of cantrips, 1st-, or 2nd level.

Magic scrolls and other magical elements are usable to martials and commoners, even if the user does not have proficiency in the arcana skill. To use a scroll, one has to tear the scroll in half to release the magic. This destroys the scroll in the process.

Any scroll of 3rd level and higher require an Arcana check to be successfully used. If the Arcana check fails, the scroll burns up without activating. If one has proficiency in arcana they have advantage on their arcana checks for using spell scrolls.

default: (a) a {@filter martial weapon|items|source=phb|category=basic|type=martial weapon} or (b) two {@filter simple weapon|items|source=phb|category=basic|type=simple weapon}
(a) a {@item light crossbow|phb} and {@item crossbow bolts (20)|phb|20 bolts} or (b) an {@item handaxe|phb|two handaxes}
(a) {@item studded leAether armor|phb} and {@item scale mail|phb}
(a) a {@item light crossbow|phb} and {@item crossbow bolts (20)|phb|20 bolts} or (b) A {@item flintlock pistol|ToL|Flintlock Pistol}
{@item architect's tools|ToL|Architect's Tools}, {@item architect's staff|ToL|Architect's Staff} and a {@item scholar's pack|phb}

classFeature.name: Sigil Scribing
entries: As an Architect, your spellcasting is centered around your ability to inscribe precise magical sigils onto specially crafted Architect's Arcane Crystals. This process combines meticulous preparation, technical expertise, and a deep understanding of arcane mechanics, setting Architects apart from other spellcasters.

At 1st level, your ability to cast spells comes from inscribing magical sigils into Architect's Arcane Crystals during a long rest. These prepared crystals are slotted into your Architect's Staff or a suitable alternative, acting as your spellcasting focus.

entries.name: Cantrips
entries: At 1st level, you know two cantrips of your choice from the Architect spell list. You learn an additional Architect cantrip of your choice at 4th level and another at 10th level. Your cantrips are ingrained in your Architect's Staff.
When you gain a level in this class, you can replace one of the Architect cantrips you know with another cantrip from the Architect spell list

entries.name: Preparing Spell Crystals
entries: During a long rest, you use your {@item architect's tools|ToL|Architect's Tools} to inscribe spells onto your crystals. For each spell slot available to you, you can scribe a spell of the corresponding level onto a crystal. You may prepare multiple crystals with the same spell, allowing you to cast the same spell more than once. You may also scribe a spell into a higher-level crystal, provided you have the appropriate spell slot.

For example, if you have four 1st-level spell slots and two 2nd-level spell slots, you can prepare four 1st-level crystals (e.g., {@spell catapult}, {@spell identify}, and two {@spell detect magic}) and two 2nd-level crystals (e.g., {@spell heat metal} and {@spell see invisibility}).
A spell can also be upcast by using a higher level crystal for the spell (e.g., {@spell catapult|xge} upcast to 2nd level)

entries.name: Casting Spells
entries: To cast a spell, you expend one of the prepared crystals containing the scribed spell. The magic within the crystal fades after use, and it cannot be reused until it is re-scribed during a long rest.
You cannot cast a spell that you have not scribed into a crystal.

entries.name: Known Spells
entries: Your knowledge of spells is vast but requires careful planning. At 1st level, you know four spells of your choice from the Architect spell list.

The Spells Known column of the Architect table shows when you learn more Architect spells of your choice. Each of these spells must be of a level for which you have spell slots. For instance, when you reach 5th level in this class, you can learn one new spell of 1st, 2nd or 3rd level.

Additionally, when you gain a level in the Architect class, you can choose one of the Architect spells you know and replace it with another spell from the Architect spell list, which also must be of a level for which you have spell slots.

entries.name: Spellcasting Ability
entries: Your spellcasting ability is Intelligence, reflecting your analytical approach to magic.

You use your Intelligence whenever an Architect spell refers to your spellcasting ability. In addition, you use your Intelligence modifier when setting the saving throw DC for an Architect spell you cast and when making an attack roll with one.

entries.name: Ritual Casting
entries: You can cast an Architect spell as a ritual if that spell has the ritual tag and you have the spell known.

entries.name: Architect's Tools and Focus
entries: Your {@item architect's tools|ToL|Architect's Tools} are essential for inscribing sigils into your crystals. Your {@item architect's staff|ToL|Architect's Staff} or a similar device (e.g., a pouch with individual crystal compartments) serves as your spellcasting focus, allowing you to channel the magic stored in the crystals.

entries.name: Architect's Arcane Crystals
entries: Your spellcasting depends on Architect's Arcane Crystals, unique to your craft and prepared through your expertise. These specially altered crystals are finely tuned to draw energy from Etheria, the Arcane Realm, recharging naturally and serving as your primary magical medium.

entries.name: Architect's Crystals
entries: You start with a set of Architect's Arcane Crystals as part of your equipment. These crystals are customized for Architect use and cannot be utilized by other arcane casters.

items: Unlike raw Arcane Crystals, your crystals do not amplify magic or grant additional effects. They serve purely as vessels for the precise spell sigils you inscribe.

entries.name: Crystal Recharging
entries: Your crystals recharge automatically by drawing arcane energy from Etheria during a long rest. This process restores them to full capacity, enabling you to prepare new spells without requiring external resources.

entries.name: Crystal Loss or Replacement
entries: If your Architect's Crystals are lost, stolen, or destroyed:

items: You must acquire new raw Arcane Crystals and spend 1 week of downtime using your {@item architect's tools|ToL|Architect's Tools} to fine-tune and prepare replacements.
This process requires access to a stable environment, such as a workshop or laboratory.

entries.name: Raw Arcane Crystals from Adventures
entries: Raw or adventured-for Arcane Crystals cannot replace your prepared Architect's Crystals. These materials may be studied, sold, or used but are unsuitable for your intricate spellcasting needs.

classFeature.name: Innovations
entries: When you reach 2nd level, your expertise in arcane engineering allows you to create Innovations—unique advancements that enhance your abilities and expand your spellcraft. These Innovations are fueled by a resource called {@bold Innovation Points}, which are central to the Architect's versatility.

entries.name: Innovation Points
entries: You gain a pool of Innovation Points, which you use to activate or maintain your passive Innovations. The number of Innovation Points you have is equal to your {@italic Architect level + your proficiency bonus}
You cannot have more Innovation Points than the maximum indicated for your level on the Architect class table.
At the end of a long rest, you regain all spent Innovation Points, except for those allocated to Passive Innovations, which remain in use until you choose to stop maintaining them.

entries.name: Types of Innovations
entries: You can select Innovations from the {@filter Architect's Innovations List|optionalfeatures|source=ToL|feature type=Innovation} when you gain this feature. Innovations are divided into two categories:

entries.name: Passive Innovations
entries: Passive Innovations provide ongoing benefits as long as they are maintained. To maintain a Passive Innovation, you must allocate the required number of Innovation Points. These points remain unavailable while the Innovation is active.
You can stop maintaining a Passive Innovation at the end of a long rest, freeing up its allocated Innovation Points. However, you may only replace or swap out one Passive Innovation per long rest.

entries.name: Active Innovations
entries: Active Innovations grant temporary enhancements or abilities that can be used when needed. Activating an Active Innovation typically requires a bonus action and consumes the specified number of Innovation Points immediately upon use.

classFeature.name: Study Path
entries: At 3rd level, you choose a Study Path that reflects the focus of your architectural studies. Your choice grants you specialized knowledge and abilities that enhance your craft. You gain unique features from your chosen Study Path at 5th, 9th, and 15th level.

classFeature.name: Quickened Scribe
entries: At 3rd level, you gain the ability to quickly adapt your prepared spells during your short rests. When you finish a short rest, you can choose one spell that you have scribed into an Architect's Arcane Crystal and replace it with another known spell of a level you can cast. The newly scribed spell takes the place of the original and must follow the usual rules for your spellcasting.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 4th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a feat.

classFeature.name: Study Path
entries: At 5th level, you gain a feature granted to you by your chosen Study Path.

classFeature.name: Moment of Brilliance
entries: At 6th level, you can quickly come up with ingenious solutions when others need it most. When you or a creature you can see within 30 feet of you makes an ability check or a saving throw, you can use your reaction to add your Intelligence modifier to the roll.
You can use this feature a number of times equal to your Intelligence modifier (minimum of once). You regain all expended uses when you finish a long rest.

classFeature.name: Tool Expertise
entries: At 7th level, you gain expertise with your tools. Your proficiency bonus is now doubled for any ability check you make that uses your proficiency with a tool.
Additionally, you gain proficiency with two tools from the Artisan's Tools List of your choice.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 8th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a feat.

classFeature.name: Study Path
entries: At 9th level, you gain a feature granted to you by your chosen Study Path.

classFeature.name: Improved Quickened Scribe
entries: At 10th level, your ability to adapt your prepared spells has significantly improved, allowing you greater flexibility in your planning. When you finish a short rest, you can replace a number of scribed spells equal to half your proficiency bonus (rounded down) with other known spells of a level you can cast. Each newly scribed spell replaces an existing spell in an Architect's Arcane Crystal, adhering to the usual rules of your spellcasting.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 12th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a feat.

classFeature.name: Master of Tools
entries: Starting at 14th level, your expertise with tools allows you to excel in nearly any situation requiring their use. Whenever you make an ability check that uses a tool you are proficient or expertise with, you have advantage on the roll.

classFeature.name: Study Path
entries: At 15th level, you gain a feature granted to you by your chosen Study Path.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 16th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a feat.

classFeature.name: Unmatched Intellect
entries: At 18th level, your brilliance and depth of knowledge allow you to solve even the most complex problems with ease. If your total for an Arcana, History or Investigation check is less than your Intelligence score, you can use that score in place of the total.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 19th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a feat.

classFeature.name: Brilliant Mind
entries: At 20th level, your unparalleled intellect and ingenuity reach their pinnacle. You can use your Moment of Brilliance feature an unlimited number of times, allowing you to provide solutions and insight in any situation without restraint.

classFeature.name: Fightning Style
entries: You adopt a particular style of fighting as your specialty. Choose one of the following options. You can't take the same Fighting Style option more than once, even if you get to choose again.

entries.name: Archery
entries: You gain a +2 bonus to attack rolls you make with ranged weapons.

entries.name: Blind Fighting
entries: You have {@sense blindsight} with a range of 10 feet. Within that range, you can effectively see anything that isn't behind total cover, even if you're {@condition blinded} or in darkness. Moreover, you can see an {@condition invisible} creature within that range, unless the creature successfully hides from you.

entries.name: Defense
entries: While you are wearing armor, you gain a +1 bonus to AC.

entries.name: Dueling
entries: When you are wielding a melee weapon in one hand and no other weapons, you gain a +2 bonus to damage rolls with that weapon.

entries.name: Great Weapon Fightning
entries: When you roll a 1 or 2 on a damage die for an attack you make with a melee weapon that you are wielding with two hands, you can reroll the die and must use the new roll, even if the new roll is a 1 or a 2. The weapon must have the two-handed or versatile property for you to gain this benefit.

entries.name: Interception
entries: When a creature you can see hits a target, other than you, within 5 feet of you with an attack, you can use your reaction to reduce the damage the target takes by {@dice 1d10} + your proficiency bonus (to a minimum of 0 damage). You must be wielding a {@item shield} or a {@filter simple or martial weapon|items|source=phb|category=basic|type=simple weapon;martial weapon} to use this reaction.

entries.name: Protection
entries: When a creature you can see attacks a target other than you that is within 5 feet of you, you can use your reaction to impose disadvantage on the attack roll. You must be wielding a shield.

entries.name: Superior Technique
entries: You learn one {@filter maneuver|optionalfeatures|source=|category=|type=maneuver, battle master} of your choice from among those available to the {@subclassFeature Battle Master|Fighter||Battle Master||3} archetype. If a maneuver you use requires your target to make a saving throw to resist the maneuver's effects, the saving throw DC equals 8 + your proficiency bonus + your Strength or Dexterity modifier (your choice).

You gain one superiority die, which is a {@dice d6} (this die is added to any superiority dice you have from another source). This die is used to fuel your maneuvers. A superiority die is expended when you use it. You regain your expended superiority dice when you finish a short or long rest.

entries.name: Thrown Weapon Fighting
entries: You can draw a weapon that has the thrown property as part of the attack you make with the weapon.
In addition, when you hit with a ranged attack using a thrown weapon, you gain a +2 bonus to the damage roll.

entries.name: Two-Weapon Fighting
entries: When you engage in two-weapon fighting, you can add your ability modifier to the damage of the second attack.

entries.name: Unarmed Fighting
entries: Your unarmed strikes can deal bludgeoning damage equal to {@dice 1d6} + your Strength modifier on a hit. If you aren't wielding any weapons or a {@item shield} when you make the attack roll, the {@dice d6} becomes a {@dice d8}.
At the start of each of your turns, you can deal {@dice d4} bludgeoning damage to one creature {@condition grappled} by you.

classFeature.name: Soul Power
entries: At 1st level, you gain access to your Soulburn Die, representing the fragments of your soul that you're willing to sacrifice for power. Your Soulburn Die starts as a {@dice d6} and increases as you gain levels in this class. Refer to the Soulburn Die coulumn of the Soulburner table

The Soulburner can utilize the Soulburn Die in various features. When rolling a Soulburn Die, the Soulburner takes damage equal to the result rolled as necrotic damage. This necrotic damage cannot be diminished or mitigated in any way. This damage goes through temporary hit points.

After each feature that allows you to roll a soulburn die. You can feel your future life being burned away, as you sacrifice your life expectancy for power. Sometimes it may be hours, days, weeks. While in other cases… Years.
Some of your Soulburner features require your target to make a saving throw to resist the feature's effects. The saving throw DC is calculated as follows:

classFeature.name: Mental Stat
entries: As a Soulburner you get to choose your own mental stat. Your options are the following: Intelligence, Wisdom or Charisma. This stat will be used as your DC modifier, and as modifier for other relavant abilties

classFeature.name: Soul Succession
entries: Starting at 1st level, you gain access to your Soul Succession ability. When you make a saving throw, you can use your reaction to roll your Soulburn Die and add the rolled amount to the saving throw result. However, you also suffer necrotic damage equal to the result rolled on your Soulburn Die.

You can use this feature once between long rests starting at 1st level. The number of uses increases to twice between long rests starting at 5th level, and to three times between long rests starting at 11th level.

classFeature.name: Soul Infusion
entries: Starting at 2nd level, your manipulation over your soul's energy allows you to imbue your weapons with elemental power.
As a Bonus Action, you can infuse your held weapon with one of three elements: Fire, Cold, or Lightning. Roll a Soulburn die and take the damage rolled.
Depending on your choice of element, your weapon is infused with said element for the next minute, dealing additional damage equal to one roll of your Soulburn die.

classFeature.name: Soul Path
entries: At 3rd level, as you delve deeper into the mysteries of soul manipulation, you choose a Soul Path that shapes the direction of your soulburner abilities. Your chosen path grants you additional features at 3rd, 7th, 10th, 15th, and 20th levels. There are four paths available: {@subclassFeature Path of the Soulstealer|Soulburner|ToL|Soulstealer|ToL|3|ToL|Soulstealer}, {@subclassFeature Path of the Soulkeeper|Soulburner|ToL|Soulkeeper|ToL|3|ToL|Soulkeeper}, {@subclassFeature Path of Greater Soulburning|Soulburner|ToL|Greater Soulburner|ToL|3|ToL|Greater Soulburner} and, {@subclassFeature Path of the Dragonsoul|Soulburner|ToL|Dragonsoul|ToL|3|ToL|Dragonsoul}.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 4th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a {@filter feat|feats}.

classFeature.name: Extra Attack
entries: Beginning at 5th level, you can attack twice, instead of once, whenever you take the Attack action on your turn.

classFeature.name: Resilient Soul
entries: At 6th level, your soul grows resilient.

Your hit point maximum increases by 6, and it increases by an additional 1 point each time you gain a level in this class. You gain advantage against the {@condition poisoned} condition and become resistant to poison damage. Additionally during a long rest, you can now recover from two points of {@variantrule Lumeeria variant: Exhaustion|ToL|exhaustion} instead of one.

classFeature.name: Soul Path Feature
entries: At 7th level, you gain a feature granted to you by your Chosen Soul Path.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 8th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a {@filter feat|feats}.

classFeature.name: Soul Flay
entries: At 9th level, You learn to tear at the very essence of your enemies' souls, leaving them weakened and vulnerable.
When you hit a creature with a weapon attack, you can choose to roll your Soulburn Die to inflict a Soul Flay effect.

To use this ability, you willingly take necrotic damage equal to the result rolled on your Soulburn Die. Then, the target must make a Constitution saving throw against your Soul Power DC. On a failed save, it suffers disadvantage on attack rolls and the next saving throw it makes until the end of your next turn.
You can use this feature Twice. Once you have expended all uses, you must finish a short or long rest before you can use this feature again.

classFeature.name: Soul Path Feature
entries: At 10th level, you gain a feature granted to you by your Chosen Soul Path.

classFeature.name: Soul Succession Enhancement
entries: At 11th level, your control over soul manipulation expands further, allowing you to extend the benefits of {@classFeature Soul Succession|Soulburner|ToL|1} to your allies in dire situations.
You can now use your {@classFeature Soul Succession|Soulburner|ToL|1} ability to aid allies within 30 feet of you as a reaction when they make a saving throw. The mechanics remain the same as before

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 12th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a {@filter feat|feats}.

classFeature.name: Soul Percision
entries: At 13th level, your control over soul manipulation allows you to augment your strikes  ensuring their accuracy at the expense of your own vitality.

When you make an attack roll and it is about to miss, you can choose to roll a Soulburn Die and add the amount rolled to your attack roll. However, using this ability inflicts necrotic damage upon yourself equal to the result rolled on the Soulburn Die.

If the added value from the Soulburn Die still does not result in a successful hit, you can choose to roll an additional Soulburn Die and repeat the process. You can continue to roll additional Soulburn Dice in this manner until you either hit your target or choose not to roll further.

You can use this feature equal to your chosen {@classFeature Mental Stat|Soulburner|ToL|1|Tol|mental stat} modifier. Once you have expended all uses, you must finish a long rest before you can use this feature again.

classFeature.name: Soul Mastery
entries: At 14th level, your mastery over soul manipulation reaches new heights, granting you unprecedented control over your {@classFeature Soul Infusion|Soulburner|ToL|2} ability. You gain the following benefits:

items: {@bold Extended Duration:} When you activate your {@classFeature Soul Infusion|Soulburner|ToL|2} feature, the duration is now extended to 30 minutes.

{@bold Multiple Infusions:} You can now maintain three different elemental infusions simultaneously. This means you can choose three different enhancements from the {@classFeature Soul Infusion|Soulburner|ToL|2} options and have all three active at the same time. However, you must still suffer the necrotic damage for each infusion activated. There can still only be one infusion active on a weapon at a time.
