{@bold Allied Infusion:} You can now extend the benefits of your Soul Infusion to allies. As a bonus action, you can infuse an allies weapon that is within 30 feet of you. Like with your own infusions, you must still suffer the necrotic damage for each ally's weapon you infuse.

classFeature.name: Soul Path Feature
entries: At 15th level, you gain a feature granted to you by your Chosen Soul Path.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 16th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a {@filter feat|feats}.

classFeature.name: Unstable Surge
entries: At 17th level, you can channel the raw, unstable power of your soul into a devastating melee attack.

As a bonus action, you unleash Unstable Surge. The next time you hit a creature with a melee weapon attack, it deals an extra {@dice 6d12} + Your chosen {@classFeature Mental Stat|Soulburner|ToL|1|Tol|mental stat} (Minimum of +1) necrotic damage.

However this comes at a price. Your accuracy wavers and for as long as the Unstable Surge is active, all your bonuses to your attack roll, including magical weapon bonuses, momentarily vanish. As well as you rolling at disadvantage.

After Unstable Surge has been used, roll a {@dice d6}. The result of the {@dice d6} determines how many long rest's you must take before using this feature again. Additionally you must roll 2 of your soulburn die. The result of these equal to the amount of years taken from your life expectancy. As you've burned away those years.

classFeature.name: Mental Mastery
entries: At 18th level, your mastery over soul manipulation extends to your mental fortitude. You gain proficiency in your saving throw of your chosen mental ability score associated with your Soul Power DC.
Additionally, you gain advantage against being {@condition charmed} or {@condition frightened}.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 19th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a {@filter feat|feats}.

classFeature.name: Soul Path Mastery
entries: At 20th level, you gain a feature granted to you by your Chosen Soul Path.

subclassFeature.name: Path of the Soulstealer
entries: With this path, you learn to harness the latent energy of your soul to drain the life force from your adversaries, replenishing your own vitality with their suffering.

subclassFeature.name: Soul Tether
entries: At 3rd level you learn how to harness the fading essence of fallen foes, using their essence to protect yourself. When death looms on the battlefield, the Soulstealer can seize upon the departing soul.

When a foe dies within 15 feet of you, you can use your reaction to extract a fragment of their departing soul. Gaining temporary hit points equal to your Soulburn die plus your constitution modifier (minimum of +1).

You can use this feature once starting at 3rd level. Twice at 7th level and three times at 10th level. At 15th level you can use the feature as many times as you want. You regain any expended uses of this when you finish a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Lifesteal
entries: At 7th level, your control over soul manipulation grants you the power to siphon the life force of your foes to sustain your own vitality. After each use you can feel the stolen life force adding to your life expectancy.

As a bonus action, you can activate your Lifesteal ability. When you make your next weapon attack against a creature, roll your Soulburn Die and add the result as necrotic damage to your damage roll. Additionally, the amount rolled is restored to you as hit points.
You can use this feature a number of times equal to your proficiency bonus. Once you have expended all uses, you must finish a long rest before you can use this feature again.

subclassFeature.name: Soulrend
entries: By 10th level you learn to tear at the very essence of your foes, causing grievous wounds that are difficult to heal.

After hitting a creature with a weapon attack, you can choose to unleash a Soulrend. If you decide to do so, roll your Soulburn Die and take the rolled necrotic damage yourself. Afterward, the target must make a Constitution saving throw against your Soul Power DC.
On a failed save, the creature cannot regain hit points until the start of your next turn.
You can use Soulrend two times per day. Once you have expended all uses, you must finish a long rest before you can use Soulrend again.

subclassFeature.name: Greater Lifesteal
entries: At 10th level, your {@subclassFeature Lifesteal|Soulburner|ToL|Soulstealer|ToL|7} ability undergoes a profound transformation.

When activating {@subclassFeature Lifesteal|Soulburner|ToL|Soulstealer|ToL|7}, you now add you chosen {@classFeature Mental Stat|Soulburner|ToL|1|Tol|mental stat} modifier to the necrotic damage dealt by the ability (minimum of +1)

subclassFeature.name: Soul Drain
entries: At 15th level, you gain the ability to unleash a devastating aura known as Soul Drain.

As an action, you unleash a aura of dread within a 10-foot radius centered on you. Each creature, friend or foe alike, must make a Constitution saving throw against the Soulstealer's Soul Power DC, taking necrotic damage equal to your soulburn die on a failed save or half as much damage on a successful one.
You heal for the total amount of necrotic damage dealt. If a creature dies from Soul Drain, then the amount healed is only the remaining hit points of the target.
The Aura of Soul Drain lasts for a duration of rounds equal to half your Proficiency bonus rounded down.
Once activated, you can repeatedly unleash waves of soul-draining power as a bonus action each subsequent round.
You need to finish a long rest before you can use this feature again

subclassFeature.name: Ultimate Lifesteal
entries: At 20th level, your {@subclassFeature Lifesteal|Soulburner|ToL|Soulstealer|ToL|7} ascends to its ultimate form, manifesting as a passive ability that triggers once a turn whenever you strike an enemy with your melee weapon using an Attack action.

subclassFeature.name: Path of the Soulkeeper
entries: Those who tread the path of the Soulkeeper eventually master the art of unleashing potent spells fueled by their own life force, controlling arcane energies with the very essence of their being.

subclassFeature.name: Sacrifical Magic
entries: Soulkeepers draw upon their own life essence to fuel their arcane abilities, sacrificing their vitality to wield powerful spells.

At 3rd level, as a Soulkeeper, you unlock the arcane potential within your soul, enabling you to cast spells fueled by your own life force. You learn to manipulate magic from the very essence of your being, using your vitality as a catalyst to manipulate the energies within the arcane realm.

To cast a spell, you must roll soulburn dice equal to the spell's level and take that amount of necrotic damage. For example, casting a 1st-level spell requires rolling 1 soulburn die, while casting a 3rd-level spell requires rolling 3 soulburn dice.

entries.name: Spell Slots:
entries: The Soulkeeper does not use traditional spell slots to cast spells. Instead, they expend soulburn dice, sacrificing fragments of their own soul to manifest arcane effects. The number of soulburn dice required to cast a spell depends on the level of the spell being cast, as outlined in the Soulkeeper Class table.

entries.name: Spells Known:
entries: Starting at 3rd level, you know three 1st-level spells from the Soulkeeper spell list. Every other level, you learn an additional spell, expanding your magical repertoire. You can choose any spell from the Soulkeeper spell list with a level you can cast. This and the total number of spells you know is listed in the Spells Known and Spell level column of the Soulkeeper Class table. The Soulkeeper shares its spell list with Wizards.
In the arcane arts of the Soulkeeper, your chosen {@classFeature Mental Stat|Soulburner|ToL|1|Tol|mental stat} serves as your conduit for casting spells.

entries.name: Spellcasting Ability:
entries: When casting spells as a Soulkeeper, you utilize your chosen {@classFeature Mental Stat|Soulburner|ToL|1|Tol|mental stat} as your spellcasting ability. This stat governs the effectiveness of your spells and determines their saving throw DC and attack rolls.
The formular for your spell save DC and spell attack modifier are as follows:

entries.name: Spellcasting Focus:
entries: You can use an {@item arcane focus|phb} as a spellcasting focus for your soulkeeper spells.

subclassFeature.name: Arcane Insight
entries: At 3rd level, you become proficient in two skills associated with your chosen mental stat as well as acquiring an arcane focus.

subclassFeature.name: Spell Predator
entries: At 3rd level, you gain the ability to harvest spells from spellcasters, absorbing their magical knowledge into your own repertoire.
As an action, you can attempt to harvest a spell from a non-friendly spellcaster within 15 feet of you.

To do so, make an Arcana check with a DC equal to the practitioner's spell save DC. On a successful check, you can choose one leveled spell from a list of three options provided by the DM, and that spell becomes permanently known to you, these spells can even be ones that are 1 level above your current casting limit. The possible spells are spells that the targeted spellcaster has access to, and the spells can only be chosen if they are in the wizard spell list.

Failure comes at a cost. If you fail the Arcana check, you immediately suffer backlash, rolling soulburn dice equal to your proficiency and taking that amount of necrotic damage. Additionally, you are incapacitated until the end of your next turn.
Once you've attempted to harvest a spell from a practitioner, the target becomes immune to further attempts from your Spell Predator feature for one month.

Alternatively, you can attempt to harvest a spell from the corpse of a spellcaster. The same rules apply, but there is no backlash for failing the Arcana check. However, the attempt might still fail for various reasons, such as the age of the corpse or the weakness of the lingering soul. Once a corpse of a spellcaster has been harvested for a spell, it is permanently immune to any further attempts from your spell predator feature.

After Spell Predator has successfully harvested a spell. Roll a {@dice d4}. The result dictates how many long rests you need to finish before Spell predator can be used again. This only happens if the Spell Predator successfully harvested a spell. Failure does not put the feature on a cooldown.
After you have acquired a spell from Spell Predator. That spell's level goes into a Predator Count.
The maximum of spells that Spell Predator can acquire are equal to your {@bold level + your chosen mental stat}.
For Example, acquiring the 3rd level spell fireball, would add 3 to the overall count. The maximum in this example would be 10 (Soulkeeper level) + 4 (Mental stat) = 14

You can choose to permanently abandoned one of these spells acquired through Spell Predator. You can do this for one spell each time you finish a long rest. After a spell has been abandoned, the spell's level is removed from the Predator Count and the spell can never be acquired again.

subclassFeature.name: Orbs of Keeping
entries: At 7th level, your character undergoes a transformation, as soul orbs manifest themselves on your body. The cosmetic characteristics of this transformation are determined by you, making them a personalized and distinctive feature of your character. The only stipulation is that these orbs must be visible to you.

For example, you might envision the orbs growing out from your collarbone Starting as marrow from the bone, gradually pushing through the surface of your skin until they become fully formed orbs affixed to your body.
Each soul orb can be used to store a reaped soul inside them until the soul is consumed.

When consuming a soul orb, each orb is considered 1 charge. For each charge consumed as a bonus action, the spell level is equal. For example, by consuming 3 charges, the soulkeeper can cast fly without having to pay the cost in soulburn dice. Similarly, the soulkeeper could consume 3 charges to upcast chromatic orb to level 3.

As a bonus action, you can consume a soul within a soul orb. Consuming a soul will make the next spell that you cast be free from rolling soulburn dice, as the spell consumes the stored soul instead of you.
The number of orbs on your body is equal to {@bold double your proficiency bonus}.
Each soul orb can be used to store a reaped soul inside them until the soul is consumed.

subclassFeature.name: Reap Soul
entries: At 7th level, you gain the ability to reap souls from recent mortal deceased humanoid creatures and store them inside your orbs of Keeping.
After reducing a creature within 30 feet of you to 0 hit points, you can as a bonus action reap the soul from the creature. Reaping a soul stores the soul in one of your unoccupied Orbs of Keeping.
You need to finish a short/long rest before you can use this feature again
Creatures whose souls have been taken from them are unable to be revived by anything other than a Wish spell.

subclassFeature.name: Memories of the Soul
entries: At 10th level, you can gaze into the memories of a soul that is stored inside one of your soul orbs.

You can spend 1 minute concentrating on a specific soul that is within your possession. After 1 minute you gaze into the memories of the soul. What you see may differ, they can be fragments, whole memories or even places that the soul remembers.
You need to finish a long rest before you can use this feature again

subclassFeature.name: Soul Glyph
entries: At 10th level, you gain the ability to inscribe a magical glyph using the energy stored within your soul orbs.

By consuming 2 charges, you can cast the {@spell glyph of warding|phb} without the need for any material components, the glyph functions exactly as described in the {@spell glyph of warding|phb} spell.

subclassFeature.name: Soul Spear
entries: At 15th level, you gain the ability to conjure a Soul Spear and potentially tether it to a target's soul, enabling you to draw upon their essence.

As an action, you consume 3 charges of soul orbs and you make a ranged spell attack against a creature within 80 feet of you. On a hit, the target takes 3 soulburn dice damage + your chosen mental stat modifier (minimum of +1)

Additionally on a hit the Soul Spear remains attached to the target and a small arcane tether goes from you to the spear. For the next spell that you cast, the tethered target will take the soulburn dice damage for casting the spell, instead of you. The tether remains for 1 minute or until a spell has been cast.
You need to finish a long rest before you can use this feature again

subclassFeature.name: Ultimate Keeper
entries: At 20th level, you unluck the full potential of your soulkeeper abilities. The cosmetic characteristics of your Ultimate Keeper form is entirely up to you.
As an Action you consume 6 charges of soul orbs and you magically transform into your Ultimate Keeper form.

items: In this form you gain 60 feet of flight

While in this form, once a turn, whenever you reduce a creature, that meets the conditions for {@subclassFeature Reap Soul|Soulburner|ToL|Soulkeeper|ToL|7}, to 0 hit points within 60 feet of you. The soul of that creature is automatically reaped and stored in your {@subclassFeature Orbs of Keeping|Soulburner|ToL|Soulkeeper|ToL|7}.
While in this form, if you have a minimum of 8 charges of soul orbs. You have advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects

While in this form, if you have a minimum of 4 charges of soul orbs. You are considered resistant to your soulburn dice damage. Taking half of all the necrotic damage you deal to yourself through Sacrificial magic.

entries: You remain in this form for 1 minute. It ends early if you are {@condition incapacitated|phb}, if you die, or if you dismiss it as a bonus action.
You need to finish a long rest before you can use this feature again.

subclassFeature.name: Path of Greater Soulburning
entries: For those who choose the path of the Greater Soulburner, the boundaries of their soul's power are pushed to their limits. They can unleash devastating attacks that exact a heavy toll on their own essence, sacrificing their soul for raw, destructive power.

subclassFeature.name: Greater Soul Infusion
entries: At 3rd level, your understanding of soul manipulation grants you access to an enhanced form of Soul Infusion, known as Greater Soul Infusion. This ability allows you to infuse your weapons with even greater elemental power.
When you activate Greater Soul Infusion, you can choose one of the following enhancements:

items: {@bold Soulfire Surge:} When you deal damage with a weapon infused with fire damage, the target must make a Dexterity saving throw against your Soul Power DC or catch on fire and take fire damage equal to 1 roll of your Soulburn Die. They take the same damage at the start of each of their turns, unless they succeed on an additional Dexterity saving throw, or they take an action to extinguish the flames.

{@bold Frostbound Edge:} When you deal damage with a weapon infused with cold damage, the target must make a Constitution saving throw against your Soul Power DC or have their movement halved until the start of your next turn.

{@bold Stormforged Strike:} When you deal damage with a weapon infused with lightning damage, the target must make a Dexterity saving throw against your Soul Power DC or take an additional 1d6 lightning damage. Additionally, if the target is within 5 feet of another creature, the lightning will arc between the two, forcing the second creature to make a Dexterity saving throw, taking 1d6 lightning damage on a failed save.

entries: Each of these enhancements follows the same mechanics as the standard Soul Infusion ability, requiring you to suffer necrotic damage equal to your Soulburn Die when activating the infusion. The only difference is that each elemental version of Greater Soul Infusion comes with additional effects tailored to its elemental nature.

subclassFeature.name: Soul Control
entries: At 7th level, your control over soul infusion reaches new heights, granting you additional ways to empower your weapons with elemental energy.
These additional methods of empowerment can also be combined with the elemental enhancements introduced through Greater Soul Infusion at 3rd level but cannot be combined with each other.

items: {@bold Soul Empowerment:} You can choose to pour more of your soul into your soul infusion, enhancing its potency. When you activate your Soul Infusion feature, you can opt to double the dice rolled both for your Soulburn Die and the elemental damage infused in your weapon. For example, at level 7, you would normally roll 1d8 for both the Soulburn Die and the elemental damage; with Soul Empowerment, you instead roll 2d8 for each.

{@bold Alternative Infusion:} You have discovered alternative sources for infusing your weapons with elemental power. Instead of sacrificing a fragment of your own soul, you tap into external sources. When you activate your Soul Infusion feature, you can choose take no damage from your Soulburn Die, but your weapon still becomes infused with the chosen elemental damage. This allows you to wield formidable power without risking harm to your own soul.

subclassFeature.name: Soul Overload
entries: At 10th level, you can harness the full extent of your soul's power, albeit at great cost.

As a bonus action, you enter the state of Soul Overload. To activate this ability roll {@dice 1d4}, the result you rolled determines the price for overloading your soul. You must roll the amount of Soulburn Die, equal to the {@dice d4} result, and take necrotic damage equal to the result.
While in this state, your weapon attacks deal maximum damage, but you cannot crit.

However, at the end of you turn, you suffer {@dice 1d4} levels of {@variantrule Lumeeria variant: Exhaustion|ToL|exhaustion}. Afterwards you suffer a backlash in your hit point maximum equal to {@dice 2d4} times 10. This effect lingers until your {@variantrule Lumeeria variant: Exhaustion|ToL|exhaustion} from soul overload is gone.

This powerful state lasts for your entire turn, after which you immediately gain the {@variantrule Lumeeria variant: Exhaustion|ToL|exhaustion} levels determined by the rolls. Once you have used Soul Overload, you cannot use it again until you complete a long rest.
After each Soul overload. Roll your soulburn die. The result from the roll is taken as years from your life expectancy. As you've burned away those years.

subclassFeature.name: Soul Cleaver
entries: At 15th level, you gain the ability to unleash a devastating cleave attack with your weapon.

As an action, each creature in a 15-foot cone must make a Dexterity saving throw against your Soul Power DC, taking your weapon damage on a failed save or half as much damage on a successful one. The weapon damage benefits from any potential infusions on the weapon

As a cost, if there are 1-3 enemies within the cone, you must roll 1 Soulburn Die and take necrotic damage equal to the result rolled. This cost increases to 2 Soulburn Dice if there are 4-6 enemies, and for 7 or more enemies, you must roll 3 Soulburn Dice.
You can use this feature three times. Once you have expended all uses, you must finish a long rest before you can use this feature again.

subclassFeature.name: Ultimate Soul Overload
entries: At 20th level, your mastery over soul manipulation reaches its zenith. Your previous Soul Overload state is now split into two. One being the Improved Soul Overload State and the other the Ultimate Soul overload State.
When you activate the Ultimate Soul Overload feature, you now push your soul to its absolute limits, abandoning your very life for overwhelming strength.
Only one of these Soul Overload States can be used once per long rest.

items: As a bonus action, you enter the state of improved Soul overload. While in this state, your weapon attacks deal maximum damage, but you cannot crit. This state lasts until the end of your next turn.
As a bonus action, you enter the state of Ultimate Soul overload You gain the following benefits when you enter your Ultimate Soul Overload state.
You're weapon attacks deal maximum damage.
Your Ultimate Soul Overload state now lasts for 3 rounds.
You can now critical strike while in the Ultimate Soul Overload state, and your critical hit range is temporarily increased by one.
You gain resistance to all damage types except Necrotic, Force and Psychic damage while in the Ultimate Soul Overload State.

entries: The Ultimate Soul Overload state remains even if you were to become incapacitated or die.
After 3 rounds in the Ultimate Soul Overload state, your soul is completely depleted and you die.
Only a Wish spell can bring a Greater Soulburner back from this Death. As it was not the death itself, but the burning of every last bit of their soul that led to their demise.

subclassFeature.name: Path of the Dragonsoul
entries: With this path, you forge a contract with a powerful dragon, slowly changing your soul forever.

subclassFeature.name: Draconic Contract
entries: You have successfully established a contract with a dragon of significant power. This contract will forever change your soul. Slowly turning you more towards the draconic.
The type of dragon that you have made a contract with also indicated your damage type for future Dragonsoul features.
Additionally you can speak, read and write Draconic.

subclassFeature.name: Draconic Defense
entries: Beginning at 3rd level, draconic features manifest themselves on your body. While you are wearing no armor, your armor class is equal to 10 + Dexterity modifier + (Chosen mental stat) modifier. You can use a shield and still gain this benefit.

subclassFeature.name: Dragon Form
entries: At 3rd level you learn how to temporarily unleash your soul's draconic power.

The cosmetic characteristics of this transformation are determined by you, making them a personalized and distinctive feature of your character. The only stipulation is that this transformation still needs to resemble your original humanoid form.
As a bonus action, you can assume your dragon form for 1 minute.
While transformed, you gain the following benefits:

items: Your jaw becomes elongated and you grow sharp fangs. Bite becomes a natural weapon for you that deals 1d6 piercing damage on a hit. You can use either Strength or Dexterity. Bite damage grows to a d8 at level 7, and again to a d10 at level 10, and finally to a d12 at level 15.

You grow sharp and deadly claws. Claw becomes a natural weapon for you that deals 1d4 piercing damage on a hit. You can use either Strength or Dexterity. Claw can be used both as an Action or Bonus Action. Claw damage grows to a d6 at level 7, and again to a d8 at level 10, and finally to a d10 at level 15.

entries: Your natural weapons from your Dragon Form can be infused by your {@classFeature Soul Infusion|Soulburner|ToL|2} feature.
You can use this feature equal to your Proficiency Bonus. Once you have expended all uses, you must finish a long rest before you can use this feature again.

subclassFeature.name: Draconic Breath
entries: Beginning at 7th level, you can unleash the destructive draconic powers that have been accumulating in your soul.

As an action you can exhale a 30-foot cone of Draconic breath. The damage as well as Saving Throw type is related to your Draconic Contract. Each creature in the cone must make a saving throw against your Soul Power DC, taking (Proficiency Bonus x Soulburn Die) on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.
Afterward you also suffer the Draconic Breath damage rolled as necrotic damage.
The Draconic Breath Cone is increased to a 60-foot cone at level 15.

subclassFeature.name: Draconic Growth
entries: At 7th level, whenever you transform into your Dragon Form, you now grow to the large size.
While in your Dragon Form, you have an extra 10ft of speed.
Any attacks you make from your natural weapons now count as magical.

subclassFeature.name: Draconic Resistance
entries: At 7th level, you become resistant to the chosen damage type in your draconic contract.

subclassFeature.name: Draconic Wings
entries: At 10th level, your Dragon Form now sprout a pair of wings from your back, gaining a flying speed equal to your current speed.
You can't manifest your wings while wearing armor unless the armor is made to accommodate them, and clothing not made to accommodate your wings might be destroyed when you manifest them.

subclassFeature.name: Improved Draconic Growth
entries: At 10th level, your Dragon Form now lasts for 10 minutes. Your form grows, as it now also includes a tail being up to 10ft long.
You can use your tail as a natural weapon, dealing {@dice 1d8} bludgeoning  damage on a hit. You can use either Strength or Dexterity.

subclassFeature.name: Draconic Attacks
entries: At 15th level, whenever you use the attack action while in your Dragon Form. You can unleash a barrage of natural weapon attacks. You make one with your bite, one with claw and one with your tail.
You can use this feature three times per long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Draconic Presence
entries: Beginning at 15th level, your soul holds the presence of a true dragon.

As an action you can unleash a roar, each creature within 80 feet of you and aware of you must succeed on a Wisdom saving throw against your Soul Power DC or become frightened for 1 minute. A creature can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success.
You can use this feature once per long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Ultimate Dragon Soul
entries: At 20th level, you have reached the pinnacle of your Dragon Form.
Now each time you enter your Dragon Form as a bonus action. You can choose to transform into an adult version of your Dragon Type, instead of the humanoid version of your Dragon Form.

items: You can now stay in this form for however long you want.
You gain a flying speed of 80ft, as well as a climbing speed of 40ft.
You grow to the size of huge.
You are immune to your related damage type.
Your Draconic Breath damage is increased to 12d12 and you now only take half of the rolled damage as necrotic damage.

subclassFeature.name: Puppeteer Sorcerery
entries: {@italic Created By : Victor}

Puppeteer sorcerers, whispered to be Velena's children, wield the dark art of manipulation. Hailing from the elusive Chained Court, these enigmatic sorcerers instill fear across Lumeeria. Their mastery over behind-the-scenes control, akin to the rumored powers of The Chained Court chills the hearts of those who possess valuable secrets. Feared for their ability to puppeteer destinies, Puppeteer sorcerers embody the unsettling legacy of Velena's shadowy offspring, leaving an indelible mark on the lands they tread.

subclassFeature.name: Puppeteer Spells
entries: You gain additional spells at the indicated levels, as shown below. They are considered sorcerer spells for you, and do not count towards the total number of spells you know.

subclassFeature.name: Pull the Strings
entries: Your charming demeanor is enough to let you get a grip on anyone’s mind, letting your words cut through doubt like daggers. You gain proficiency in Persuasion, or expertise if you are already proficient in it. Additionally, you can give yourself advantage on a Persuasion check an amount of times equal to your Proficiency Bonus per long rest, utilizing basic manipulation to influence others.

subclassFeature.name: Controlled Companion
entries: You can control the movements of smaller objects with ease, tricking those around you into believing they contain some sort of life. You can perform a Connection Ritual by spending 10 minutes concentrating on a Tiny object, holding it throughout the process. After the 10 minutes have passed, invisible strings connect your fingetips to the object, letting you manipulate it at a distance up to 60 feet, and if the object would have a way of seeing, it can act as if you had casted {@spell Find Familiar}. The object has an AC of 10 + your PB, and has 1 hit point and becomes unusable if it takes any damage. It is immune to psychic damage.
An object connected to you lasts until you perform the ritual again or if it is destroyed. While the object is connected to you, you can use it as a spellcasting focus for your sorcerer spells.

subclassFeature.name: No One's Marionette
entries: You gain resistance to Psychic damage, as well as advantage on saves against being {@condition frightened} or {@condition charmed}.

subclassFeature.name: Force The Hand
entries: Your ability to charm and control others has grown significantly, allowing you to temporarily change the flow of combat to your advantage. As an Action, you can spend 2 sorcery points to attempt to puppeteer a creature within 60 feet of you. If a creature has Legendary Actions, or similar abilities, they are automatically immune to this feature.

The target makes a Wisdom saving throw, becoming Bound to you on a failed save. While bound, you can use your bonus action to decide what action the Bound creature will take. If you try to command it to do something that would bring direct harm to itself (Jumping in a pit of spikes, leaping out of a window, etc.), the target immediately escapes the bind. A Bound creature can repeat the saving throw at the end of their turn.
When you reach 11th level in this class, you can have 2 creatures Bound at the same time. When you reach 16th level in this class, you can have 3 creatures Bound at the same time.

subclassFeature.name: What Is Dead May Never Die
entries: Over time, you have realized that fallen warriors are not entirely useless, as long as you know how to work with a dead body. Luckily for you, you do. When a small or medium humanoid creature within 60 feet of you falls to 0 HP, you can use your reaction to cause ethereal strings to hold it upright, gaining a temporary ally. You can use a Bonus action on each of your turns to control the creature, which has the statistics of a Skeleton with any and all appropriate changes. When using your reaction, you can also spend sorcery points to empower your hold over the deceased target, giving it an amount of Temporary Hit Points equal to 5 times the amount of sorcery points spent + half your level (Rounded up) in this class. You are considered to be concentrating on this.

subclassFeature.name: Unwilling Devotion
entries: When a creature is affected by an Enchantment spell you cast, or a subclass feature, you can attempt to change their memory, as with {@spell Modify Memory} cast at its base level.

subclassFeature.name: Sever the Strings
entries: When a creature is freed from either {@subclassFeature Force the Hand|Sorcerer||Puppeteer|ToL|6} or an Enchantment you have cast on them, you can use your reaction and spend sorcery points to deal psychic damage to the creature equal to your level + an amount of d6s equal the amount of sorcery points spent. You can only spend an amount of sorcery points on this feature equal to half your level in this class, per long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Master of Puppets
entries: At 18th level, you gain the ability to channel all of your manipulative energy into a physical manifestation of control. As an action, you spend 6 Sorcery Points and gain the following benefits for 1 minute:

items: You gain immunity to Psychic damage, as well as being {@condition frightened} or {@condition charmed}.
At the start of every turn, you can choose whether or not a creature either Charmed or Bound to you takes psychic damage equal to your Charisma modifier + your Proficiency Bonus.
When you deal Psychic damage with a spell or class feature, you can add your Charisma Modifier to the damage roll.
Creatures have disadvantage on their save against {@subclassFeature Force the Hand|Sorcerer||Puppeteer|ToL|6}.

subclassFeature.name: Lumeerian Gunslinger
entries: {@italic Inspired from Matthew Mercer's Gunslingers and altered to fit Lumeeria}

In the vast and varied world of Lumeeria, where magic and technology intertwine in unexpected ways, Gunslingers are a rare breed of warriors who have mastered the art of wielding firearms with deadly precision. Armed with their trusty pistols, rifles, or other exotic firearms, Gunslingers navigate the dangers of their world with a blend of steely resolve, quick reflexes, and a keen eye for their target.

subclassFeature.name: Firearm Proficiency
entries: Upon choosing this archetype at 3rd level, you gain proficiency with {@item Tinker's Tools}.

Your proficiency with {@item Tinker's Tools} allows you to maintain, repair, and even create firearms. You can use your Tinker's Tools to craft ammunition, repair damaged firearms, or even design and construct new firearms, subject to your Dungeon Master's discretion. Your knowledge of firearms and their mechanisms grants your insight into their operation, giving you an edge in combat and ensuring your weapons remain in top condition.

subclassFeature.name: Firearms: Ammunition
entries: All firearms require specialized ammunition to function properly. Due to their rarity, finding ammunition for firearms can be challenging. However, with your proficiency in Tinker's Tools, you can craft your own ammunition at half the cost using gAethered materials. Each type of firearm typically uses its own unique ammunition, which is often sold or crafted in batches to ensure compatibility with the weapon's design. As a Gunslinger, your ability to craft ammunition ensures that you're never caught unprepared when the bullets start flying.

subclassFeature.name: Firearms: Firearm Properties
entries: Firearms come in many different variations all from small flintlock pistols to large expensive sniper rifles.
Firearms in Lumeeria have replaced the optional ones presented in the {@table Adventuring Options; Firearms|DMG|Dungeon Master's Guide}.
Firearms can be found in the {@table Lumeerian Gunslinger: Firearms Table|ToL|Firearms Table}.

subclassFeature.name: Adept Marksman
entries: When you choose this archetype at 3rd level, you learn to perform powerful trick shots to disable or damage your opponent using your firearms.

entries.name: Trick Shots:
entries: Trick Shots. You learn four trick shots of your choice, which are detailed under {@subclassFeature Gunslinger: Trick Shots|Fighter||Lumeerian Gunslinger|ToL|3|ToL|Trick Shots} below. Many trick shots enhance an attack in some way. Each use of a trick shot must be declared before the attack roll is made.
You learn one additional trick shot of your choice at 7th, 10th, 15th and 18th level. Each time you learn a new trick shot, you can also replace one trick shot you know with a different one.

entries.name: Grit:
entries: You gain a number of grit points equal to your Intelligence modifier (minimum of 1) + your proficiency bonus. You regain 1 expended grit point each time you roll a 20 on the d20 roll for an attack with a firearm. You regain all expended grit points after a long rest.

entries.name: Grit:
entries: Some of your trick shots require your targets to make a saving throw to resist the trick shot's effects. The saving throw DC is calculated as follows:

entries.name: Bullying Shot:
entries: You can use the powerful blast and thundering sound of your firearm to shake the resolve of a creature. When making a Charisma (Intimidation) check, you can expend one grit point to gain advantage on the roll.

entries.name: Dazing Shot:
entries: When you make a firearm attack against a creature, you can expend two grit points to attempt to dizzy your opponent. On a hit, the creature suffers normal damage and must make a Constitution saving throw or suffer disadvantage on attacks until the end of their next turn.

entries.name: Deadeye Shot:
entries: When you make a firearm attack against a creature, you can expend two grit points to gain advantage on the attack roll.

entries.name: Disarming Shot:
entries: When you make a firearm attack against a creature, you can expend one grit point to attempt to shoot an object from their hands. On a hit, the creature suffers normal damage and must succeed on a Strength saving throw or drop one held object of your choice and have that object be pushed 10 feet away from you.

entries.name: Forceful Shot:
entries: When you make a firearm attack against a creature, you can expend one grit point to attempt to trip them up and force them back. On a hit, the creature suffers normal damage and must succeed on a Strength saving throw or be pushed 10 feet away from you.

entries.name: Piercing Shot:
entries: When you make a firearm attack against a creature, you can expend one grit point to attempt to fire through multiple opponents. On a hit, the creature suffers normal damage and you make an attack roll with disadvantage against every creature in a line directly behind the target within your first range increment.

entries.name: Winging Shot:
entries: When you make a firearm attack against a creature, you can expend one grit point to attempt to topple a moving target. On a hit, the creature suffers normal damage and must make a Strength saving throw or be knocked {@condition prone}.

entries.name: Violent Shot:
entries: When you make a firearm attack against a creature, you can expend one or more grit points to enhance the volatility of the attack. If the attack hits, you can roll one additional weapon damage die per grit point spent when determining the damage.

entries.name: Blinding Shot:
entries: When you make a firearm attack against a creature, you can expend two grit points to attempt to blind your target with a well-aimed shot. On a hit, the creature suffers normal damage and must succeed on a Constitution saving throw or be blinded until the end of its next turn.

entries.name: Concussive Shot:
entries: When you make a firearm attack against a creature, you can expend five grit points to unleash a concussive blast with your shot. On a hit, the creature suffers normal damage and must succeed on a Constitution saving throw or be stunned until the end of its next turn.

entries.name: Staggering Shot:
entries: When you make a firearm attack against a creature, you can expend two grit point to disrupt their balance and coordination. On a hit, the creature suffers normal damage and must succeed on a Dexterity saving throw or have its movement speed reduced to 0 until the end of its next turn.

entries.name: Swift Shot:
entries: You can expend one grit point to make a lightning-fast shot, allowing you to fire your firearm with incredible speed. When you use this trick shot, you can make one additional firearm attack as a bonus action on your turn. This bonus action cannot benefit from any other trick shots.

entries.name: Disrupting Shot:
entries: You can expend one grit point to fire a disrupting shot that interferes with a creature's concentration. On a hit, the creature suffers normal damage, and if it is concentrating on a spell, it must make a Constitution saving throw with disadvantage to maintain concentration from the damage of this attack.

entries.name: Harassing Shot:
entries: You can expend one grit point, to fire a harassing shot that distracts and annoys your target. On a hit, the creature suffers normal damage and must succeed on a Wisdom (Insight) check against your Trick Shot DC or it has disadvantage on attack rolls against creatures other than you before the end of your next turn.

entries.name: Startling Shot:
entries: You can expend one grit point, to fire a shot designed to startle your opponent, causing them to lose focus momentarily. On a hit, the creature suffers normal damage, and it must succeed on a Wisdom saving throw or have disadvantage on its next saving throw until the end of its next turn.

subclassFeature.name: Quickdraw
entries: When you reach 7th level, you add your proficiency bonus to your initiative.
Furthermore, when you roll for initiative, you can expend up to a maximum of 3 grit points to boost your initiative score. For each grit point spent in this way, your initiative score increases by 2,

subclassFeature.name: Quick Thinking
entries: Upon reaching 10th level, your sharp wit and quick reflexes enable you to recalibrate your aim when your shots go awry in the heat of battle.

As a reaction to missing with an attack roll, you can add your Intelligence modifier to the roll to potentially hit the target. If the modified roll is successful, you also add your Intelligence modifier to the damage dealt.
You can use this feature three times per long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Quick Movement
entries: Starting at 15th level, you gain an additional 10 feet of movement, and you can use the {@action Disengage}, or {@action Dash} action as a bonus action.

subclassFeature.name: Vicious Intent
entries: At 18th level, you regain a grit point on a roll of 19 or 20 on a d20 attack roll. Additionally you now learn all trick shots and you regain all your grit points on a short and long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Way of the Soul Guide
entries: {@italic Reflavor of Long Death Monk to fit the narrative of Dangur}

Monks of the Way of the Soul Guide, are beings that are touched by the Retriever of Evildoers. The few that Kalin, The Black Angel chooses, are destined to look over the transition between life and death for the most wicked of souls. Soul Guides are a sacred people, that is deeply respected by the few that know of them. Soul Guides help uphold the divine balance that keeps the world of Lumeeria from descending into chaos.

subclassFeature.name: Soul Touch
entries: Starting when you choose this tradition at 3rd level, your connection to death allows you to extract vitality from another creature as it nears its demise. When you reduce a creature within 5 feet of you to 0 hit points, you gain temporary hit points equal to your Wisdom modifier + your monk level (minimum of 1 temporary hit point).

subclassFeature.name: Guide of the Corrupt
entries: Starting when you choose this tradition at 3rd level, you gain the ability to guide the corrupt souls to the plane of Judgement, Uzelon.

You can spend a minute to collect the soul from a humanoid corpse. This ritual can fail for various reasons, whereas some examples for the reasons are as follows. If the soul is no longer there, if the humanoid was not of the evil alignment or if you already hold a corrupt soul in your body.

Successfully performing the sacred ritual, you now carry with you the corrupt soul in your body. This can lead to various experiences and dangers, such as hearing persuasive whispers, catching glimps of memories or even becoming possessed. But it all depends on the soul.

When you are located at a temple of Kalin, The Black Angel, you can spend an hour performing a ritual where you implore Kalin to appear and receive the corrupt soul, so that she can lead it to Uzelon. For each corrupt soul that you guide to Kalin, you grow stronger, as shown on the Guide of the Corrupt Table.
After Guide of the corrupt has been used, and the corrupt soul is gone from your body. You must take a long rest before using this feature again.

items: By spending a bonus action observing a humanoid, you can make an insight check against their deception check. If you succeed, you learn if the target is of the evil alignment or not.
You gain a dragonfly spirit, as per the spell {@spell Find Familiar}, requiring no material component.

You can as a bonus action manifest black ethereal feathered wings on your back that give you a flying speed equal to your speed. After a minute the wings disappear. You can do this once per long rest.
You no longer need to be located at an temple of Kalin, to implore her to appear.
You have advantage on initiative rolls.
You can now cast the {@spell Plane Shift} spell once per day.
Once per long rest, as a free action you can channel necrotic energy into your unarmed strikes and for one turn you deal 1d(Martial Die) extra necrotic damage.

items.name: Keeper of The Corrupt
entries: You attempt to banish yourself and a creature to an endless demiplane. You touch a creature and the target must suceed on a Wisdom Saving throw against your Ki Save DC. On a fail, both you and the target are transferred to a realm of infinite emptiness removed from all other planes.
Within this realm, neither you or the creature age or need to breathe, eat, drink or sleep and are functionally immortal. You cannot be reduced below 1 hit point.
Time flow feels normal for you, but in truth it is a 100 times slower. Escape through conventional magical means, including teleportation or planat travel, is impossible.
You can end this effect as an action.
Alternatively, the target of this feature, can make a Wisdom check against your Ki Save DC, this can be done after 1 minute since arrival. On a success the effect ends.
Each failure increases the waiting period before another attempt can be made, from 1 minute to 1 hour, 1 day, 1 year, 1 decade, 1 century and ultimately capping at 1 millenium.

Upon conclusion of the effect, both you and the target are returned to your original locations or to the nearest unoccupid space, with your original hit points from when the Keeper of the Corrupt was initially activated.
Keeper of the Corrupt can be done once every 7 days.
{@italic Keeper of the Corrupt is greatly inspired by AdramastesGM on Instagram}

subclassFeature.name: Eyes of Death
entries: At 6th level, you gain the ability to unsettle or terrify those around you as an action, for your soul has been touched by death. When you take this action, each non-friendly creature within 30 feet of you that can see you must succeed on a Wisdom saving throw or be {@condition frightened} of you until the end of your next turn.

subclassFeature.name: Death's Ally
entries: Beginning at 11th level, you use your connection with death to escape its grasp. When you are reduced to 0 hit points, you can expend 1 ki point (no action required) to have 1 hit point instead.

subclassFeature.name: Touch of the Corrupt
entries: Starting at 17th level, your touch can channel the energy of death into a creature. As an action, you touch one creature within 5 feet of you, and you expend 1 to 10 ki points. The target must make a Constitution saving throw, and it takes {@dice 2d12} necrotic damage per ki point spent on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

subclassFeature.name: Steward of Balance
entries: Stewards of Balance is a secret global organization that self-proclaim themselves as the stewards of Zybris, The Judge of Souls.
This organization is infamous for being Neutral to the affairs of the world, only venturing out of their hidden temples if a name has been fated.
Stewards of Balance have the ability to essentially become anyone, where they use their manipulative abilities for the greater good of the cosmic balance.

subclassFeature.name: Stewards of the many faces
entries: Stewards have the ability to become anyone.

When a humanoid dies near you, you have 12 hours to attempt to extract their persona. When extracting a persona you spend an hour attempting to surgically remove their face along with their personality, memories and mannerism. You must succeed on a Intelligence check to successfully collect their persona
You can spend a minute to put on a face. You can have an amount of faces equal to your Intelligence Modifier plus your Proficiency Bonus.
You can remove one face from your collection whenever you short rest.

subclassFeature.name: Socially Intelligent
entries: Starting at 3rd level, your intellect gives you confidence in social situations. You add your intelligence modifier to all charisma skills checks.

subclassFeature.name: Quick Mind
entries: Starting at 3rd level, your quick thinking lets you act quicker. You can give yourself a bonus to your initiative rolls equal to your Intelligence Modifier.

subclassFeature.name: Undoubtable Trust
entries: Starting at 9th level, you can use the trust of others to your advantage. While wearing a face of someone and you are conversing with an individual who undoubtably trusts the face. You can choose to auto succeed any Charisma Skill Check against the individual.
You can use Undoubtable Trust an amount of times equal to your Intelligence Modifier per long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Deceptive Confusion
entries: Starting at 9th level, you can for a short time cause a target to become confused and charmed by you.

You can as a bonus action, target a humanoid creature within 30ft. Your face flickers momentarily in that creatures vision and they see their loved ones instead of you. The target must succeed on an Wisdom (insight) check against your deception. If they fail, they are charmed by you until the end of your next turn. While they are charmed by you in this way, you have advantage on the attack rolls against them.
You can use Deceptive Confusion an amount of times equal to your Proficiency Bonus per long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Insightful Technique
entries: Starting at 13th level, you can use your insight about your enemies to your advantage.

Whenever you are fighting an individual that is associated with a face from your collection. You can on the first attack made on each of your turns, add your intelligence modifier to your attack and damage rolls. You do not need to be wearing the face to gain this benefit.
Examples of association can be. Same Guild, Same Cult, Same Party, Same Clan.

subclassFeature.name: Insightful Precision
entries: Starting at 17th level, you gain the ability to strike at your enemies with a deadly precision
Whenever you are fighting an individual that is associated with a face from your collection. You gain the following benefits.

items: You attacks score a critical hit on a roll of 19 or 20.
You ignore the previous requirements for gaining sneak attack. However, if you have disadvantage on the attack roll, you still cannot gain sneak attack.

subclassFeature.name: Aether Touched
entries: Aether Touched Wizards are wizards who have, in some way, been affected by the Aetherwall and have managed to glean some of its untamed magical secrets. These wizards display abilities that break the rules of the multiverse, which even gods cannot do.

subclassFeature.name: Aetheric Adaptability
entries: Starting at 2nd level, you gain the ability to adapt your spell repertoire on the fly, reflecting the unpredictable nature of the Aetherwall.

When you finish a long rest, roll your adaptability die and record the number rolled. Once per day, as a bonus action, you can swap a prepared spell with a different spell from your spellbook of the same level or lower.
The adaptability die starts as a d4 and changes to a {@dice d6} at {@i 6th level}, {@dice 2d4} at {@i 10th level}.
At {@i 14th level}, you no longer roll the adaptability die. Instead you can choose to swap any spell of 9th level or lower with any other spell of 9th level or lower in your spellbook.
{@bold For example}, if you are a 6th-level wizard, you roll a 5 on your adaptability die. You can then swap a prepared second-level spell with an unprepared third-level spell from your spellbook.

subclassFeature.name: Aetheric Manipulation
entries: Starting at 6th level, you gain the ability to reshape and manipulate the raw arcane energies around you to your will. When you cast a leveled spell that deals damage, you can change the damage type to force damage.
You can use this feature a number of times equal to your Intelligence modifier per long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Aetheric Resilience
entries: Starting at 6th level, the chaotic energies of the Aetherwall have fortified your body against the raw energy of magic. You gain resistance to force damage.

subclassFeature.name: Aetheric Insight
entries: Starting at 10th level, you can use your reaction to reroll an initiative roll, attack roll, saving throw, or ability check that you make. You must use the new roll. You can use this feature a number of times equal to half your Intelligence modifier (Rounded down) per long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Mastery of the Aether
entries: Starting at 14th level, you can now use your Aetheric Adaptability feature twice per day.

subclassFeature.name: Aetheric Shield
entries: Starting at 14th level, you gain the ability to bend magic to your will to work as a shield against other magical sources.

You can as a bonus action surround yourself or an ally, within 30ft of you, with a Aetheric Shield. While under the Aetheric Shield you have advantage on all saving throws. The Aetheric Shield lasts for 1 minute and does require you to maintain concentration.

subclassFeature.name: Soulwarden
entries: The path of the Soulwarden is a path of absolute defense where the might of shields and chains bring down enemies to their knees.

subclassFeature.name: Way of the Warden
entries: Beginning at 3rd level, you embrace the Way of the Warden, abandoning all weapons.
You become proficient in heavy armor.
Additionally while you are wearing Heavy Armor and wielding no weapon, only a shield. You gain a bonus to your armor class equal to half your (Chosen mental stat) modifier (Rounded up)

subclassFeature.name: Dangerous Shields
entries: At 3rd level you learn how to use your shields as formidable weapons.
While two-hand wielding your shield, you can as an attack bludgeon someone using your strength modifier. Your shield has the following statistics.
{@italic Shield, melee weapon. 10gp, 6lb. Ac +2. 1d8 Bludgeoning - Two-handed}
Dangerous Shields lets your shield, when used as a weapon, be targeted by your Soul Infusion feature.

subclassFeature.name: Chains of the Warden
entries: At 3rd level, you learn to use the chains of the warden.
As an action, you target a creature within 30 feet of you. You then roll an amount of soulburn die equal to your Proficiency bonus and take the damage rolled.
The targeted creature must make a strength saving throw, on a failed save ethereal chains materialize around them for up to 1 minute. You must maintain concentration on this effect.

For each time the target is attacked, while the ethereal chains hover around the target, a new chain materializes. If the target is struck a number of times equal to half their challenge Rating (minimum of 3) they become paralyzed for 1 minute. At the end of each of their turns, the target must make a constitution saving throw. On a success, they break free from the paralyzed effect.
Chains of the Warden can only be active once at a time.

subclassFeature.name: Defensive Aura
entries: Upon reaching 7th level, you learn how to establish a defensive aura that shields your allies.

Whenever a friendly creature is within 10 feet of you, they gain a bonus to their armor class equal to half your (Chosen mental stat) modifier (Rounded up). This bonus disappears the moment they leave the range.
You must be conscious to grant this bonus.
This does not stack with the Way of the Warden bonus.

subclassFeature.name: Warden's Leap
entries: At 7th level, you gain the ability to leap to your allies.

As a reaction to an ally getting targeted by a melee attack or an ally having to make a Dexterity based Saving Throw, you can leap to a friendly creature within 30ft of you. Upon landing next to your ally, you either now become the new target of the designated melee attack or you willingly fail the Dexterity based Saving Throw and in return shield your ally, from making the saving throw.
At 15th level, the range for Warden's Leap increases to 60ft.
Warden's Leap can be used a number of times equal to your Proficiency Bonus per long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Warden's Shield Wall
entries: At 10th level, you gain the ability to summon forth a formidable barrier of shields to protect yourself and your allies in battle.

As a bonus action, you plant yourself firmly on the ground, restricting your movement to 10 feet per round, as you conjure a large, translucent, and ethereal wall of shields. The Shield Wall spans 25 feet in width and stands 10 feet tall, with you positioned at its center.

While active, the shield blocks all ranged attacks and spells originating from the opposite side of the Soulwarden, except for Area of Effect spells that spread around corners, such as fireball.  A Disintegrate spell destroys the shield immediately. Any damage coming from attacks originating from the opposite side is transferred to the shield, which has an amount of HP equal 5 times your level.
Anyone positioned behind the Shield Wall gains total cover. Once the Shield Wall is destroyed, it disappears. Individuals can pass through the wall from either side.

If the Soulwarden becomes {@condition grappled}, {@condition incapacitated}, {@condition paralyzed}, {@condition petrified}, {@condition prone}, {@condition restrained}, {@condition stunned}, or {@condition unconscious}, the Shield Wall disappears.
The Shield Wall remains active for 1 minute and can be canceled with a bonus action.
You can use Warden's Shield Wall twice per long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Reactive Warden
entries: Starting at 15th level, you gain an additional reaction per turn.

subclassFeature.name: Warden's Grace
entries: Starting at 15th level, you learn the Warden's Grace. As a reaction when you or a creature you can see within 60ft of you suffers a critical hit, you can turn that hit into a normal hit. Any effects triggered by a critical hit are canceled.
Whenever you use Warden's Grace you then Roll two soulburn dice and take the damage rolled.
You can use this feature twice per long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Ultimate Warden
entries: At 20th level, you have reached the absolute pinnacle of your defensive capabilities as the Ultimate Warden.
As an action you magically grow to the huge size as your chains start spinning around you and you enter the Ultimate Warden form.

items: While in this form, any of your Dangerous Shields attacks deal an extra 2d12 damage, Additionally you have 10 feet of reach.
While in this form, your Defensive Aura is extended to 20 feet out from your center.

While in this form, you can at the end of each of your turns, roll one Soulburn die. You take the damage rolled and half of the damage taken is added to your armor class until the start of your next turn.
While in this form, your spinning chains cause enemies within 30 feet to have their speed reduced by half

entries: You remain in this form for 1 minute. It ends early if you are incapacitated, if you die, or if you dismiss it as a bonus action.
You need to finish a long rest before you can use this feature again

subclassFeature.name: The Demon
entries: You have made a pact with a demon from the Abyssal floors. A being whose aims are evil, even if you strive against those aims. Such beings often desire the corruption or destruction of all things, ultimately including you. Plunging the world into chaos and waging war against the gods are the sole reason for these beings existence.

subclassFeature.name: Expaned Spell List
entries: At each indicated Warlock level, The Demon adds the listed spells to your known spell list.

subclassFeature.name: Demon's Gift
entries: Starting at 1st level, when you reduce a hostile creature to 0 hit points, you gain temporary hit points equal to your Charisma modifier + your warlock level (minimum of 1).

subclassFeature.name: Demon's Gambit
entries: Starting at 6th level, you can call on your patron to alter fate in your favor. When you make an ability check or a saving throw, you can use this feature to add a {@dice d10} to your roll. You can do so after seeing the initial roll but before any of the roll's effects occur.
Once you use this feature, you can't use it again until you finish a short or long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Demonic Endurance
entries: Starting at 10th level, you can choose one damage type when you finish a short or long rest. You gain resistance to that damage type until you choose a different one with this feature. Damage from magical weapons or silver weapons ignores this resistance.

subclassFeature.name: Cast Into The Abyss
entries: Starting at 14th level, when you hit a creature with an attack, you can use this feature to instantly transport the target through the abyssal floors along the Anchor Chains. The creature disappears and hurtles through a nightmare landscape.

At the end of your next turn, the target returns to the space it previously occupied, or the nearest unoccupied space. If the target is not a fiend, it takes {@dice 10d10} psychic damage as it reels from its horrific experience.
Once you use this feature, you can't use it again until you finish a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Circle of Wilderness
entries: Druids of the Circle of Wilderness are fierce guardians of the wilds. They haunt the deepest parts of the wilderness, where they might go for weeks on end before crossing paths with another humanoid creature, let alone another druid.

A druid of this circle might prowl as a great cat one night, soar over the treetops as an eagle the next day, and crash through the undergrowth in bear form to drive off a trespassing monster. The wild is in the druid's blood.

subclassFeature.name: Untamed Wild Shape
entries: You gain the ability to use {@classFeature Wild Shape|Druid||2} on your turn as a bonus action, rather than as an action.
Additionally, while you are transformed by {@classFeature Wild Shape|Druid||2}, you can use a bonus action to expend one spell slot to regain 1d8 hit points per level of the spell slot expended.

subclassFeature.name: Circle Forms
entries: The rites of your circle grant you the ability to transform into more dangerous animal forms. Starting at 2nd level, you can use your {@classFeature Wild Shape|Druid||2} to transform into a beast with a challenge rating as high as 1 (you ignore the Max. CR column of the Beast Shapes table, but must abide by the other limitations there).
Starting at 6th level, you can transform into a beast with a challenge rating as high as your druid level divided by 3, rounded down.

subclassFeature.name: Natural Ferocity
entries: Starting at 6th level, your attacks in beast form count as magical for the purpose of overcoming resistance and immunity to nonmagical attacks and damage.

subclassFeature.name: Primordial Avatar
entries: At 10th level, you can expend two uses of {@classFeature Wild Shape|Druid||2} at the same time to transform into an air elemental, an earth elemental, a fire elemental, or a water elemental.

subclassFeature.name: Natural Adaptation
entries: By 14th level, you have learned to use magic to alter your physical form in more subtle ways. You can cast the {@spell Alter Self} spell at will.

subclassFeature.name: Circle of the Swarm
entries: Druids that are part of the Circle of the Swarm believe that the foundation of nature and regrowth, lies with the critters in microbiomes that tend to be forgotten, such as: insects, arachnids and worms. Without these creatures flowers would not get pollinated, mushrooms would spread too fast and bodies would not decompose. These druids either gather in their own small colonies, living as a hivemind, or travel into the world with their own hive living in the body of the druid host in a symbiotic relationship.

subclassFeature.name: Hive Mind Link
entries: As a druid of the Circle of the Swarm, you possess a unique connection to insects, allowing you to claim and command them with a hive mind-like control.

entries.name: Claiming Insects
entries: You can sense the presence of nearby insects within your hive range by performing a 1-minute ritual. After completing the ritual, you become aware if there are enough insects nearby to form one of the swarm types. If sufficient insects are present, you can claim control over them by either expending a use of your {@classFeature Wild Shape|Druid||2}, or after completing a short or long rest. You can claim a number of swarms up to your Proficiency Bonus + Wisdom Modifier.
Once you claim a swarm, you cannot claim another for 24 hours.

You can only have an amount of swarms actively controlled equal to your proficiency bonus at any given time. Active swarms obey your commands and can participate in combat or other tasks. Active swarms in combat shares your initiative count, but takes their turns immediately after yours.
Non-active swarms remain under your control but cannot follow commands or interact in a significant way until activated. Non-active swarms can be made active by a bonus action.

Once claimed, the insects fall under your mental influence, obeying your telepathic commands and moving according to your will. If left without specific instructions, they return to their natural behavior, always staying within your hive range, until commanded again. The control lasts indefinitely as long as the swarm remains within your hive range .
Your hive rang is calculated with Proficiency Bonus x 30 feet from you.

If a claimed swarm leaves this range for more than a number of hours equal to your level x 2 (for example, a level 2 druid can maintain control for 4 hours), the swarm reverts to its natural instincts and can no longer be telepathically commanded by you without performing the ritual again.

entries.name: Telepathic Commands
entries: While active swarms are within your telepathic range, you can as an action issue simple commands, to one swarm at a time, such as attacking, scouting, assisting or protecting something. The insects follow these commands to the best of their ability and intelligence. Insects claimed by you do not act aggressively toward you or your allies unless directed to do so.

entries.name: Insect Swarm Examples
entries: When using Hive Mind Link, you can gather and claim swarms of tiny creatures. Here are the amounts of insects needed to form various types of swarms:

rows: Swarm of Insects (ants, flies, gnats etc.)
Mostly found in damp and dark places.
Mostly found in damp and dark places.
Requires effort to gather due to their varied habitats.
Reclusive and harder to find in large numbers.
Aggressive and dangerous, requiring careful collection.
Abundant in decaying environments but fragile

subclassFeature.name: Swarm Master's Command
entries: At 6th level, your bond with the swarm deepens, allowing you to wield the collective power of your swarm with precision and versatility. You gain access to several specialized commands that enable you to use your swarms in new ways.

At 6th level, you learn three of these commands.  You learn an additional command of your choice at 9th, 13th and 17th level.  You can replace one command you know with a different one after finishing a long rest.

entries.name: Symbiotic Vitality
entries: Your connection with your swarm becomes a source of healing for you or your allies. As a bonus action, you can sacrifice one of your active swarms that is within 30 feet of the target to heal them. The target regains hit points equal to the swarm’s remaining hit points. Once used, the swarm is immediately destroyed, as they wither away.

entries.name: Enraged Swarm
entries: When you are struck in combat, your swarms retaliate fiercely. When a creature hits you with a melee attack, you can use your reaction to command one of your active swarms to rush at the attacker. The swarm moves up to its speed and, if within range, makes a melee attack against the creature. If the attack hits, the creature must succeed on a Strength saving throw or be knocked {@condition Prone||prone}, overwhelmed by the mass of insects.

entries.name: Swarming Restraint
entries: Your control over the swarm allows you to restrain enemies with sheer numbers. As an action, you can command one of your active swarms to latch onto and overwhelm a small or tiny creature within 10 feet of the active swarm. The creature must make a Strength saving throw. On a failed save, the swarm {@condition Restrained||restrains} the creature for up to 1 minute. The creature can attempt to break free at the end of each of its turns by succeeding on a Strength saving throw.

entries.name: Shielding Swarm
entries: You can command your active flying swarm to form a protective barrier around you or an ally. As a reaction, when you or an ally within 30 feet is targeted by an attack, you can command one of your active flying swarms to intercept the blow, granting the target +2 AC until the start of your next turn. The swarm takes the same amount of  damage if the attack still hits.

entries.name: Blinding Swarm
entries: As an action, you can command an active flying swarm to engulf an enemy's face, obscuring their vision. Choose a creature within 30 feet; they must make a Constitution saving throw or be {@condition Blinded||blinded} for 1 minute as the swarm moves over and engulfs their face. The creature can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns to end the effect. The blinded creature can still target the swarm without the attack being at disadvantage.

entries.name: Hive Vision
entries: As a bonus action you can choose an active swarm, you then perceive through the active swarms senses (sight and sound). The active swarm can still receive your telepathic commands even after it's left your range for as long as you remain in Hive Vision. While in hive vision you are deaf and blind with regard to your own senses.

entries.name: Natures Sacrifice
entries: As an action, you can choose an active swarm within 5 feet of yourself or an ally to sacrifice. The swarm is destroyed, and the chosen creature regains a spell slot of a level equal to half your proficiency bonus (rounded up).

entries.name: Relocation Command
entries: As an action, you can magically teleport to the location of one of your active swarms within your hive range, as long as you can see it (including through your Hive Vision Command). Upon teleporting, the swarm is sacrificed and destroyed.

subclassFeature.name: Insect Portal
entries: At 10th level, your deep connection to insects allows you to harness their collective power to create temporary gateways for swift travel over great distances.

By performing a 1-minute ritual, you can sacrifice 3 of your claimed swarms to form an Insect Portal at your current location. The sacrificed swarms merge with the earth, creating a dull, ring-shaped structure made from their remains. Once established, this portal connects to other Insect Portals that you have previously created.

To activate an Insect Portal, you must spend one use of your {@classFeature Wild Shape|Druid||2}. Once activated, the portal remains open for 1 minute, allowing creatures of Large size or smaller to pass through it. The portal can transport you and others to the location of any previously established Insect Portal.

Each Insect Portal remains dormant after creation for up to one year. To keep the portal functional, you must sacrifice another swarm before the year ends. If no sacrifice is made, the portal deteriorates and becomes unusable.

You can maintain a number of active Insect Portals equal to your Wisdom modifier (minimum of 1). If you create a new portal beyond this limit, one of your existing portals of your choice will close permanently

subclassFeature.name: Perfect Synchronization
entries: At 14th level, your hive mind has been perfected, allowing you to enter perfect synchronization where you take on the abilities and traits of your swarm.
As an action you can spend a use of {@classFeature Wild Shape|Druid||2}, to take on abilities and traits of any active swarm.
You remain in Perfect Synchronization form for 1 minute. It ends early if you are incapacitated, if you die, or if you dismiss it as a bonus action.
You can choose from the different Swarm types and their abilities below.
Every swarm gives these standard buffs.

items: Gain resistance to non-magical bludgeoning, piercing and slashing
+2 to armor class
Gain 22 points of temporary hit points.
Your weapon attacks add Wisdom to their overall modifier and deal an additional {@dice 3d6} + druid level as poison damage.
You can as a reaction to getting hit by a melee attack deal {@dice 3d6} + druid level to the enemy attacker.
Gain resistance to both non-magical and magical bludgeoning, piercing and slashing
+4 to armor class

Gain {@spell Spider Climb}, {@footnote Web Sense |While in contact with a web, the spider knows the exact location of any other creature in contact with the same web.|Web Sense, Monster Manual(Giant Spider)} and {@footnote Web Walker |The spider ignores movement restrictions caused by webbing.|Web Walker, Monster Manual(Giant Spider)}
Gain climbing speed of 30ft
While in form, you can cast the {@spell Web} spell at will.
Gain flying speed of 60ft

Upon moving at least 30ft toward and enemy, they need to make a wisdom saving throw, on a failure they become {@condition Frightened} of you for 1 minute. They can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of their turns.
As an action you can sling maggots over to a friendly creature within 30ft, the maggots remove any {@condition Poisoned} conditions and heals the target {@dice 3d6} + druid level.

subclassFeature.name: Study of Constructs
entries: Architects who pursue the Study of Constructs devote their talents to bringing life to their creations, crafting magical entities from arcane crystals and mechanical ingenuity. These Architects blend engineering expertise with advanced arcane knowledge to animate constructs capable of carrying out their commands.

For them, every construct is an extension of their own skill and intellect, a testament to their mastery over form and function. Whether it's a crystalline automaton patrolling the battlefield, a helper repairing delicate mechanisms, or a defensive sentinel standing guard, these constructs are more than simple servants—they are living proof of the Architect's unmatched craftsmanship.

Those who follow the Study of Constructs embrace the challenge of designing creations that adapt to any situation, forging allies that grow alongside their makers. In the Architect’s hands, the lifeless becomes vibrant, as arcane engineering pushes the boundaries of what is possible.

subclassFeature.name: Architect's Protector
entries: At 3rd level, your expertise in arcane engineering has enabled you to create a loyal construct companion, the {@creature architect's protector golem|ToL|Protector Golem}. This construct is an extension of your skill, designed to aid you in battle and protect those under your care. The {@creature architect's protector golem|ToL|Protector Golem} is friendly to you and your allies and follows your commands faithfully. Its appearance reflects your design preferences—whether a sleek humanoid figure, a sturdy quadrupedal automaton, or another shape of your choosing—but this choice does not affect its game statistics.

In combat, the {@creature architect's protector golem|ToL|Protector Golem} shares your initiative count, but it takes its turn immediately after yours. It can move and use its reaction independently, but it only takes the Dodge action on its turn unless you use a bonus action to command it to take another action. The action can be one listed in its stat block or any other action it is capable of. If you are incapacitated, the {@creature architect's protector golem|ToL|Protector Golem} acts on its own, taking any actions it deems necessary to protect you or your allies.
If the {@spell Mending} spell is cast on the {@creature architect's protector golem|ToL|Protector Golem}, it regains {@dice 2d6} hit points.

If the golem is reduced to 0 hit points, you can use your {@item architect's tools|ToL|Architect's Tools} as an action to revive it. You must be within 5 feet of the golem and expend a spell slot of 1st level or higher to repair it. After 1 minute of work, the {@creature architect's protector golem|ToL|Protector Golem} returns to life with all its hit points restored.

At the end of a long rest, you can create a new {@creature architect's protector golem|ToL|Protector Golem} if you have access to your {@item architect's tools|ToL|Architect's Tools}. If you already have a {@creature architect's protector golem|ToL|Protector Golem}, the first one ceases to function immediately when the new one is completed. If you die, your {@creature architect's protector golem|ToL|Protector Golem} ceases to function after 10 minutes.

subclassFeature.name: Architect's Helper
entries: Starting at 5th level, your skill in crafting constructs has advanced to the point where you can create small, utilitarian golems to assist you in your daily life. These Architect's Helper Golems are designed for utility rather than combat, streamlining tasks and enhancing your productivity outside of battle.

To create an Architect's Helper Golem, you must spend 6 hours of downtime, 50 gold worth of resources and have access to your {@item architect's tools|ToL|Architect's Tools}. You can have a total number of Helper Golems equal to half your level at any given time. At 20th level, you can have unlimited Helper Golems.
Each golem can be either Small or Tiny in size, depending on its intended function.
Helper Golem Characteristics:

items: {@bold AC:} 10
{@bold Hit Points:} 1
{@bold Strength:} 4
{@bold Abilities:} Helper Golems cannot attack or perform any action requiring significant strength or dexterity.
